To pull off the style, you’ll want to invest in a quality styling products that offer a loose and naturally textured finish.

The Korean undercut is a modern haircut that will elevate your style and create the necessary contrast needed to highlight the styling above. The undercut offers a versatile cut on the sides and back that can be combined with all the most popular men’s hairstyles. Asian men can pair the undercut with a slick back, comb over, crew cut, side part, bowl cut or curtains hairstyle for a dapper finish.

The two block haircut features trimmed hair on the sides and back that sharply contrasts with longer hair on top, creating a cool disconnected style that has become popular with Korean men. This short layered cut is similar to an undercut and can be partnered with several charming styles such as the long fringe, bowl cut and middle part. To get the perfect look, make sure to use a lightweight styling product that will leave your hair loose for a softer look. Great for casual and formal occasions, the two block hairstyle will continue to be a trend for years to come.

The Korean fade is a tapered haircut that gradually blends the hair on the sides and back shorter for a sleek finish. The fade haircut has become the most popular cut for guys to get and works with all hair types, lengths and styles. There are many different types of fades to consider and guys can choose between a low, mid and high fade haircut. For extra flair, you can ask your barber to cut a skin, drop, or burst fade. With a modern touch, Asian men will love the added visual appeal of the taper fade.

A short hairstyle for Korean men can offer a low-maintenance look that is masculine and easy to style. There are several great short haircuts to consider, including the crop top, buzz cut, comb over fade, slicked back undercut and curtain fringe with tapered sides. Guys who want short hair should start with a fade, taper or undercut on the sides and back to set the foundation for the shorter style on top. For a structured style, use a strong pomade or wax product to keep your hair in place all day. A light styling clay or cream can be the perfect option for a shaggy natural look or guys who want to maintain longer bangs for a parted style.

The medium hairstyle for Korean guys provides texture, length and styling options for a bolder look. Whether you have straight, thick, wavy or curly hair, medium haircuts look better with tapered sides that will accentuate the irresistible style on top. When it comes to styling your hair, you can get a hard side part, quiff, pompadour, brush back, two block with bangs or flowing style with the right products. Use a matte hair product for a textured finish or a pomade with some sheen for a sexy wet look.

The long hairstyle has always been a popular choice for Korean men who want styling flexibility and that heartthrob KPop style. The longer hair on top is often complemented by shorter cut sides to construct the perfect foundation for a range of styles. From flowing shoulder length hairstyles to the man bun and top knot, guys can experiment with different long styles to find a youthful and classy look.

Korean men who have curly hair should appreciate the unique texture and style that curls can offer. Korean curly hairstyles start with short cuts on the sides and back to create the edgy and fashionable looks that highlight their curls. Some guys prefer short curly hair paired with an undercut and messy styling, while others may choose a permed style with tight curls and faded sides. If you’re looking to stand out, an Asian man with curly hair is sure to impress.

The comb over is a classic haircut for Korean men who want a business professional style that suits all occasions. As the most popular variation, the comb over fade has become a hot hair trend and can be tailored to fit your look. You can ask your barber for a high, mid or low taper fade on the sides and back to create a cut that suits your needs. The low comb over fade offers an elegant and versatile style, while the mid and high skin fade can amp up the boldness. Talk to your stylist about featuring a hard part to highlight the cut and consider using a glossy styling product like pomade for a formal finish.

The buzz cut is a military-style haircut that Korean guys can choose to get a masculine and low-maintenance style that requires minimal styling. Buzzed hairstyles can be cut one length all around or faded on the sides and back for a modern take. Whether you have short or long hair, there are many buzz cut styles to consider for a fresh look. A close-cropped top with a high skin fade can be turned into a high and tight. For a longer style, the crew cut is a versatile cut with extra length on top where the hair in front can be side swept for a preppy and charming touch.

The messy hairstyle is a casual and cool look that can help Korean men exude confidence and a sexy bad boy vibe. Messy hair has been a style embraced by KPop stars and can be applied to many different haircuts. From trendy fringe hairstyles to curtains, bowl cuts and shaggy tops, these messy styles need a light-hold product that offers definition, volume and a matte finish.

The middle part is a popular Korean hairstyle that provides men with a stylish look and versatility. A middle part can be styled with short or long hair on top and an undercut or taper on the sides. Some Korean guys will add waves to the curtains for a textured style, while others prefer straight hair for a cleaner look. When styling a middle part, you’ll need a lightweight product like clay, wax or cream to avoid weighing down your strands. Like a KPop celebrity, you’ll want to style your hair to maximize flow, volume and movement.

The Korean bowl cut is a modern style that features short hair on the sides and back with longer hair on top and in the front. The bowl haircut has become a fashionable trend and continues to be a KPop-inspired style that women love to see on Korean men. You can style your hair shaggy and messy or neat and all brushed forward. With the right cut, this hairstyle requires minimal styling with a quality product that adds texture and fullness.

The Korean side part is a classic haircut for men that combines tapered or undercut sides with longer hair on top to create an elegant style. The side part can be a great hairstyle for the modern gentleman who wants a business professional cut for work that also looks attractive at a club. This dapper style is often neat and structured but Korean guys can pull off a loose parted look for a casual finish.

The Korean slicked back hairstyle is a modern take on the classic style that looks bold and sexy. With an undercut on the sides and back, slicked back hair works well with guys who have thick straight locks. To pull off a cool slick back, make sure to use a strong pomade or wax and brush your hair up and back to infuse volume.

The Korean perm is a chemical treatment for men that can help add a curl or wave to straight hair for an irresistible look. While there are different types of Korean perms, most guys choose to style an undercut on the sides and short curly or longer wavy hair on top. These permed hairstyles have become popular fashion trends and offer a cool way to transform your look.

Korean curtain bangs are an iconic hairstyle for men who have longer hair and want a sexy style that frames their face while offering a trendy look. The curtains haircut features short hair on the sides and back with long bangs that are used to created a defined middle part. As a popular style for Korean men, the fringe can be messy and wavy for a textured finish or simple and straight for a clean look. To maximize volume and flow, make sure to apply a light styling product and blow dry your hair.

The Korean quiff is a chic style that requires guys to brush their hair up and forward for an eye-catching finish. The quiff haircut starts with a fade or undercut and medium to longer hair on top that can be styled to create a casual or clean-cut professional look.

The shaggy hairstyle is one of the coolest and easiest styles for Korean men to experiment with. Shag haircuts are versatile, textured and messy styles that work with all hair types for a carefree look. This fun and youthful style looks good when you don’t want to put any effort into styling your hair.

Cornrows are among the best and most popular braid hairstyles for men. Tight and clean, cornrows are compact and easy to maintain, but they retain a fashionable edge that makes them iconic. It’s one of the reasons cornrows have been around for years, and they’ll be around for many more as this traditional form of braiding is flexible. Because cornrows are so versatile and low-maintenance, these types of braids have become common with athletes like Russell Westbrook, Allen Iverson, and Kawhi Leonard.

Box braids are synonymous with the likes of ASAP Rocky, an artist famous for his fashion sense as much as his lyrics. What sets box braids apart for most men is that they aren’t attached to the scalp – they’re sectioned off in squares along the scalp instead. This means they are easy to position in a variety of angles and forms, from traditional box braids for men where the plaits dangle from the back and sides of the head to a ponytail or man bun.

Man bun braids are for the guys who don’t want their plaits to hang loose all of the time. If you’d rather your hair didn’t cover your face or come back to your shoulders and back, you can tie them into a man bun. Like a typical bun, the style is ideal for when you need to be on-trend but don’t have the time. Some men turn it into a practical and stylish cut by plaiting a thicker braid around the edges of the head, leaving the center to be styled with more intricate designs.

Braids for boys are less manly and masculine, suiting their soft features. Usually, boys’ braided hairstyles result in complex patterns that show off children’s desire to always be on top of the latest trend. The fishbone design is an iconic cut for boys.

Dread braids combine two hairstyles into one by taking classics and mixing them together for the ultimate style. What’s instantly obvious is how much texture you get when you decide to braid dreadlocks, as well as the extra volume. The thickness of your hair means you’ll be able to hold styles with less effort, so you can switch up the braiding technique without too many worries or hours of tying! Dread braids are brilliant for men with short hair as shorter cuts prevent them from appearing feminine.

Braids with an undercut ensure that the main feature of your style – the plaits – stands out and doesn’t fade into the background. Braids are box office, yet pairing them with an undercut takes it to another level as the sleek nature of your back and sides contrast the longer style on top. Also, there are different versions of undercuts, from faded to disconnected, so your braids will never feel old or tired.

If you want a cool haircut that’s sharp and versatile, braids with a fade are for guys who don’t want to go over the top with their plaits. Sometimes, it’s easy to get caught up in making your braids as big and full of volume as possible, but it can lead them to appear wild and untamed. Implementing a fade allows you to maintain a level of control without losing any of the style as you can simply add plaits to the top hair. The different textures, along with the subtle-yet-powerful contouring from your fade, will leave you looking fresh.

You don’t have to wait a year to grow out your hair since guys can get braids for short hair. The key is to keep the back and sides compact like you would with a regular short style. For example, you can opt for an undercut or a taper fade and leave the top hair longer. With the extra length on top, it’s easy to push the strands upward and tie them into place. As well as the bold contrast, braids for short hair offer lots of creative takes on a classic trend.

Braids for long hair are ideal if your hair grows out rather than down. While it has volume, it lacks the length that you want, which is where plaits come into play. By pulling your hair tight and braiding it down towards your shoulders, you’ll finally get the fully-long trend that you’ve been growing for months. You will need to tie your hair into at least three to four plaits on each side of your head to pull off the effect.

You can wear single braids in a variety of ways. Like box braids, you can position them individually so that you utilize the clean-cut fashion that is synonymous with individual plaits. For those who want something less classically stylish, you can place a single braid around the edge of your head and add cornrows to the space in the center.

Two braids are perfect for men with thick hair. The style isn’t as subtle or sophisticated as single braids, yet the easy design is very eye-catching. The regular way to wear double braids is to run two separate plaits from the front of the head to the back; however, you implement extra coolness by forming them into double man buns. As far as fashionable and original braids go, you don’t get more unique multiple buns!

Three braids are great for creating a look that’s full of impact, but that’s also easy to tame. Depending on the style, you can have long or short hair, so it’s a very versatile design that’s helpful for guys who want to add another dimension. Typically, one braid goes down the center of the head while the other two are towards the sides to create extra coverage.

Four braids are harder to maintain because there are more plaits to fix into position, but men love the volume that they provide as they make the style appear thicker. Plus, the additional braids are ideal for trying different trends as you can mix and match them with everything from faded sides to wavy lines in-between the individual plaits.

Rather than going from the front to the back, side braids swerve towards the direction of your ears, introducing a twist on a classic that’s simple to pull off. It’s generally better for guys who want short braids that are thin because long and thick plaits can appear too bulky. Of course, if you prefer to keep more hair on top as it’s thinner, you can incorporate a side braid to ensure you don’t miss out on a cool trend.

Top braids are confined to the top of the head, so you don’t get much coverage on the back and sides. This braid style is often paired with a fade or shaved sides to highlight the design on top. This way, the contrast of the braids on the top will work perfectly with the shorter length, not to mention the fact that there are tons of different options, from single and double plaits to dreads and locs that flow into a man bun.

Long hair is usually the most suitable kind for braids because it provides styling options, but that doesn’t mean small and short designs aren’t accessible. The key is to make sure that you have enough length to manufacture your plaits into place with around three to four inches being a good length. Then, it’s all about making your aesthetic as small as possible with the help of microblading techniques that allow for tight and intricate looks. An undercut is ideal for small braids as it emphasizes them.

Large braids require anywhere between five and ten inches of hair. The longer your hair, the larger your twists will be and the more eye-catching your braided hairstyle will look. A prime example is a Viking-inspired braid that runs from the back of the head down to the shoulders and back area. Twinned with a beard and a bold undercut on the sides, you’re guaranteed a masculine vibe that’s straight-up Nordic warrior.

Feed-in braids start thin at the front and get thicker and longer as they work their way backwards. The varying width is a fantastic way to add shape and texture to your hair without losing any sophistication since the thin braids at the front aren’t overly in your face. Feed-ins are also flexible, so you can increase or decrease the number of plaits depending on your mood.

Braids don’t have to flow in one direction or be styled into a single design, like the braided mohawk shows! By taking your twists and pulling them into a mohawk shape in the center of your scalp, you’ll create a version of a bold cut that is even more daring, especially if the sides are shaved and clean.

A braided ponytail is a manly, eye-catching design that’s right up your street if you’re tired of straight back hair or a man bun. Like a Viking-inspired braid, it culminates with a single ponytail at the back. If you feed three twists along the center and sides of the head into a lengthy ponytail, you’ll style some badass braids.

A crown braid is a cut that’s fit for a king. With one long, thick plait that circles the length of your head, or two on either side, if you prefer, you create a crown effect that’s regal as it leaves plenty of room for intricate designs in the space that’s left. Opt for a symmetrical pattern for an ultimate royal look.

Spider braids are a style that’s a variation on box braids; however, the difference is the pattern that’s shaved into the crown. Spider braid styles have a straight line and diagonal lines that intersect it. The result is a spider-like body, with the box braids acting as the legs.

Easy braids tend to be simple and very low-maintenance, yet it’s their clean-cut aesthetic that makes them appealing. The best examples are single plaits as they’re minimal, but you can add another dimension by pulling it into a top knot or man bun that is as equally casual and smart.

There are lots of original and eye-catching trends to try with braids, so you shouldn’t get stuck in a rut. If you see a fresh design that you love and want to attempt, don’t be afraid to head to the barbers and tell them what you saw! You can Google a picture and take it with you if you’re unsure how to describe the style.

Straight plaits are the norm, which is why zig-zag braids are great at diversifying your image and adding a level of excitement that you don’t get when your cut looks the same. Guys love a zig-zag pattern because it can be designed in a number of ways, from hanging loose to a tighter braid, like the elaborate fishbone style. Above everything else, zig-zags are fun and creative.

French braids are named after the style that developed in Europe and that was synonymous with women for a long time. But, as society has evolved, French braids for men have become sophisticated and handsome ways for guys with straight hair to obtain a cut that’s normally associated with Afro-Caribbean hair. You’ll need a single long plait that’s intertwined with side braids for this classic look.

Straight hair braids are doable, but you’ve got to let your hair grow out or else it won’t braid and twist into place. Once you’ve got the right amount of growth, you should go for lots of small, tightly plaited braids so that you get the correct thickness to pull off the aesthetic.

A long, braided ponytail at the back is always a winner for braids for white men since it has a Scandinavian feel. You don’t only have to opt for the warrior Viking pattern, though, because Dutch braids that feed into a short ponytail or man bun are ideal for white guys, too. Use a disconnected undercut to add more intricacy.

A short hair perm is a low-maintenance and trendy hairstyle. If you want the volume a longer curly hairstyle offers, but without all of the weight, this is a great option. Your curls will be tighter and more defined this way, and the perm gives off a youthful look.

A perm with medium length hair is the more relaxed and effortless version of this technique. You can keep the curls more natural by using a curl cream or go for a more professional appearance by using a curl-defining spray. No matter how you style it, this easy cut will shine.

Achieve that rocker image by going with a long hair perm. Stemming from the 70s, this curly hairdo is a modern twist on a retro classic. When deciding to go with this longer hairstyle, make sure to grow your hair out more than usual because once curled it will be shortened.
If you’re really looking to bring back this old-school curly hairstyle, you can pair it with a trimmed goatee or a bushy beard.

Curly hair can be styled a number of ways, including combining a perm with a fade. A popular option for the modern man, the short hair on the fade emphasizes the curls even more and makes it appear that your hair has more volume than it does. If you go with a fade, you can pick from many different types of fade haircuts.
Whether you choose a low, mid, high, skin, bald, drop, temp, or taper fade, the men’s perm will always be the focus. Versatile and trendy, you’ll be able to style your curly or wavy hair on top in a number of cool ways to experiment with different styles.

You can further define your curls by going with a perm and undercut. The undercut essentially does the same thing as a fade, creating contrast and emphasizing your curly hair on top. However, an undercut gives you that little bit of extra edge and works well with a hard part or line up. To make the contrasting lengths really stand out, keep the hair long on top to create a long fringe.

A loose perm features more relaxed curls and a more casual finish. Whether you just want wavy hair or loose curls, this style works can be enhanced with a light cream or mousse for extra control, texture and volume.
We also recommend you keep the sides short with a fade or undercut to focus the eyes on the styling on top. Ultimately, the loose curl perm is a favorite among guys.

A tight perm can be more difficult to style, but well-defined curls can also be completely worth the extra trouble. The tight curls perm is ideal for short to medium-length hair. Use a strong pomade or curl-enhancing smoothie to keep the kinky coils on top bouncy and frizz-free.

A wavy perm can be achieved when your curls start to loosen and stretch out, eventually transforming into waves. Wavy hair can also be the result when men try to perm medium length to long hair. Ultimately, wavy perms offer a unique textured style that can elevate any good men’s hairstyle. Guys should use a light styling product like mousse or cream to control yet maximize the wavy effect.

Light perms can be great for men with long hair. How lightly your hair gets permed depends on the strength of the treatment process as well as how thick and straight your locks are beforehand. Generally, a light perm can give you cool waves that are well-suited for most trendy hairstyles.

One of the most on-trend men hairstyles is a perm with a fringe. A curly hair fringe takes advantage of natural curls and makes bangs. Keeping the fringe long in front creates drama on top and is an option for men who wish to cover their foreheads. While you can keep the hair the same length all the way around, you can pair this fringe with a fade to draw even more attention to the permed hair in front.

Add a little more drama by combining your curly hair with a comb over. The perfect look for men with short to longer hair, the comb over perm is a diversion from a normal side part since guys can get more creative with their styling. Whether you sweep your curls all the way over to one side or let some of your hair hang over your forehead, the hairstyle is meant to be sophisticated and fashion-forward.

Nom: Curly Perm Hair Crop Top Fade
Description: Another good team up with a perm is a French crop. A permed crop top fade hairstyle keeps the hair on the sides short and uniform to accentuate the hair on top. It also works for men with different face shapes and hair textures. However, if you decide to go for this styling, make sure to keep the hair long enough on top to highlight the curls and to achieve the classic cropped haircut.

Nom: Curly Hair Perm with Drop Fade
Description: For those interested in going for an extreme appearance and to shake up the norm, a perm with a drop fade is the way to go. To achieve this hairstyle, your stylist will likely curl the center and either leave the side hair straight or curl it as well. If the sides are straight, the style will blend better into the drop fade. This contrast in lengths is extremely modern and striking.

A curly faux hawk is the latest take on the classic mohawk. The fohawk works nicely with wavy, thick, and straight hair since you have the volume and bounce already built-in. Your barber will keep the sides short with a fade or undercut to highlight the styling on top. To style, simply add hair products to push and spike the hair in the center.

Get that classic sun-kissed look when you bleach your perm. The blonde hair stands out, especially in the summer, and can be worn by a wide variety of men. If you’re interested in this style, make sure to give yourself enough time between bleaching and curling as both require chemicals and you don’t want to damage or dry out your hair.

To create even more definition, pair your perm with a hard part. This curly side part hairstyle is all about contrast, and looks particularly stylish with a skin fade on the sides and back. Your stylist will shave a thick line to create the hard part, and you’ll want to part your hair naturally to the other side of your head.

Permed hair with a long fringe is a great way to boost your natural curls. A short fringe works well with this type of permed men’s hairstyle, but a longer fringe with curls creates even more volume and dimension to your overall look. It can also be an option for men who wish to cover their larger foreheads.

Try upgrading your style by pairing a mid fade with a perm. This is a substitute to an undercut for those you are looking for a less severe appearance but still want the edge that a skin fade haircut provides. The mid fade will highlight your curls on top and keep you looking fresh and fun.
An alternative to a side part, the middle part with a perm is perfect as a cool curly style. Popular during the 90s, this parted hairstyle is simple yet stylish, and will stand out in any crowd.

Be a trendsetter by going full out with a mohawk perm. This look is bolder and more daring than a faux hawk but can be styled tastefully, if necessary. To style a curly mohawk, you’ll need to use styling products and blow-dry the look in place.

If you’re wanting even more volume on top, try pairing your curls with a pompadour. This timeless hairstyle may have been made famous by Elvis Presley, but modern men are updating the pompadour. A straight hair pompadour is traditional and easy, whereas teaming it with curly hair creates a more dramatic and tousled appearance. This style can be achieved with short or long hair, depending on your cut and look.

Boost your curls to the next level by going with a voluminous perm. Perming your hair doesn’t just achieve a head of luxurious curls, it can also be to give your hair volume and thickness. Getting this look is similar to the traditional process accept, you remove the shaping rods before a neutralizer is applied. Your curls will be looser and will naturally fall around your face.

A digital perm is a popular modern type of hot perm that results in softer, looser curly hair. Instead of a traditional perm, the digital perm uses hot rods with a temperature system that is controlled by a machine that has a digital display. The process thermally reconditions men’s hair, allowing your curls to last longer. Effective and fashionable, most men love how soft, smooth, and shiny their curly hair feels after a digital perm.

A body wave perm for men gets you a looser type of curl. Ideal for medium to long hair that doesn’t easily hold curls, body waves can give you the necessary texture and styling required for a trendy wavy hairstyle.

The white guy perm looks good with many of the best men’s hairstyles today. Popular curly styles include tapered, faded or undercut sides with short to medium-length curls on top styled into a fringe. Apply a light styling product for a clean, handsome finish.

Black men with permed hair can enjoy a variety of cool, rugged hairstyles. Long and messy curly black hair looks great with a temp fade. On the other hand, short to medium-length perm hairstyles can be low-maintenance and easy to achieve. Pair the look with a beard for a sexy, handsome look.

Asian men like being able to change up their hairstyles with a perm. Known for their thick straight hair, Asian guys with permed hair can benefit from a new dimension to their style. From waves to tight curls, experiment with an Asian perm for texture, volume, and flair.

Teenage boys are loving the perm. Boys with permed hair look stylish, especially when they get the curly fade haircut. Loose or tight, perm hairstyles stand out in the crowd at school. Invest in a good hair product to stop frizz and keep the look in place all day.

The modern mohawk is an elegant hairstyle for men that plays off the classic mohawk but comes with a taper fade haircut on the sides and back. Similar to a faux hawk, the stylish mohawk fade haircut can be short or long on top but must be spiked to create the daring style. Universally flattering with limitless styling options, you can ask your barber for different taper fades to achieve your favorite look.

The taper fade mohawk is the stylish and modern variation of the traditional hairstyle. The taper fade adds a clean, polished look to the mohawk haircut, softening the traditionally edgy and bold lines needed to cut the look. For the punk rocker who still needs to go to work the next day, a mohawk with a taper fade on the sides and back is worth experimenting with.

The short mohawk fade is a versatile style for guys who prefer a stylish shorter haircut. With a taper fade on the sides and back, the short hair on top is cut to create a simple spiky mohawk hairstyle. You can get a low, mid or high fade haircut to complement the styling you want. To style the look, your short mohawk will need to be at least around the length of a crew cut on top to give you defined spikes. There are many options for achieving a mohawk fade with short hair and staying true to the original haircut. You can keep the hair on top narrow to highlight the difference in length or keep the sides almost shaved with a high skin fade.

If you want to stand out, the mid fade mohawk is a cool hairstyle that looks edgy and classy at the same time. The mid fade tapers to the skin about halfway down the sides and back to create a trendy mohawk hairstyle. This cut adds structure and dimension to your haircut in a way that will allow you to stand out in any crowd.

The low fade mohawk is a trendy haircut for guys who prefer a subtle edgy look. Modern and sexy, pairing the mohawk with a low fade softens the tapered cut between the long hair on top and the hair on your sides and back by starting the fade closer to the ears. The more subdued nature of this fade offers you the versatility of spiking your hair into a cool mohawk or letting your hair flow naturally when you want a more casual style.

The skin fade mohawk is a daring and fashionable hairstyle that will demand attention everywhere you go. Like a mohawk, the skin fade haircut is inherently bold and blends into the scalp. The short hair on the sides contrasts the long hair on top but complements the style in a way that will let your inner rebel loose. This modern mohawk hairstyle with a skin fade can closely resemble the classic rockstar look when spiked, creating a badass look with attitude.

The high fade mohawk is a strong, masculine haircut that exudes confidence and coolness. A high fade starts above your temples, close to the crown of your head, drawing the eye upward toward your mohawk and contrasting sharply with the long hair on top. Be aware that whether you opt for a high skin fade or a high taper mohawk, bringing your hairline closer to the crown of your head will always make your hairstyle stand out more. You might consider pairing this mohawk with a beard to add the ultra-masculine appeal.

The mohawk fade is a versatile men’s haircut that works for long hair, creating a stylish look for guys who prefer a longer style. With a tapered haircut on the sides, the long mohawk fade offers a striking look that maximizes contrast between the short sides and long top while also delivering a flattering style. You’ll want to use a product with a higher hold when it comes to keeping your hair long for the mohawk since the hair will be heavier and more prone to falling to one side.

The burst fade mohawk is one of the most popular hair trends for guys who want a cool style that stands out. The burst fade will taper the sides to create a stylish look, while the mohawk is one of the coolest hairstyles in barbershops around the world. A burst taper fade starts at the ears and curves around the head, blending the hair on the sides and down to the neck. By creating a semicircle, this type of fade is unique and fashionable. You can ask your barber for a low, mid, or high burst fade to get the perfect cut for your desired look. The mohawk can be styled with different lengths and hair types, including short, long, straight, thick, wavy and curly hair. Add some stubble or a thick beard for a ruggedly handsome look.

The drop fade is a stylish way to upgrade any mohawk hairstyle without being too extreme. A drop fade mohawk will add structure to your face as it follows the natural curve of your head around the back and sides, dropping towards the neckline as it flows away from the temples. If you’ve only cut a basic short fade until now, you’ll want to ask your barber to add a drop fade to your mohawk for a trendy look.

The temple fade mohawk is a sharp and sleek hairstyle for black men that always looks great. The temp fade haircut features a cool tapered cut that will accentuate the mohawk, resulting in a clean and fresh look. Whether you have thick curly hair or an afro with a high top, a mohawk with a temp fade is a style worth exploring.

When it comes to getting a smooth and sexy cut, the bald fade mohawk is an amazing hairstyle that will make a bold statement. The bald fade haircut is a short cut that tapers your hair into the skin, offering a sharp and edgy vibe with contrast. Great for guys who want very short sides and longer hair on top, you can ask your stylist for a high, mid or low fade. A low bald fade with a mohawk might be ideal if you need a business professional style, whereas the mid or high fade will transform your look.

A mohawk fade with line designs is one of the hottest modern trends for a bold gentleman who wants to get artistic with his haircut. Getting a mohawk with a design involves shaving patterns into the fade on the sides or back of the head, adding another dimension to the cut. You can ask your barber for ideas or come up with your own haircut designs to get extra creative. While the lines can be simple or intricate, your mohawk fade will be bold and sharp. You’ll need to make regular trips to your barbershop if you want to keep your lines and designs looking fresh.

Black men in barbershops around the world have been experimenting with the afro mohawk fade. Easy to get and simple to style, a mohawk with afro hair is a stylish and low-maintenance hairstyle for guys with longer, coarse hair. This cool afro fade haircut will mean that less product is needed to keep the hair upright, giving it a more natural look. Pair your mohawk with a temp fade and short full beard to look like a boss everywhere you go. You can even complement the style with twists to create a unique finish.

The mohawk and beard symbolize masculinity, rebellion and unshakable confidence, making these styles a natural fit. The mohawk fade with a beard is a popular look that requires proper grooming and care for a clean yet rugged style. You can pair your beard with a low fade mohawk for a cool and classy cut or add a high skin fade to your hairstyle for maximum contrast between your hair and beard. You can even taper your beard into your sides for a faded look. We recommend using a quality shampoo and conditioner to keep your beard soft and manageable, then use a balm and brush when styling your facial hair to keep it flowing in the same direction.

The curly hair mohawk fade is a great men’s hairstyle when you want to highlight your curls with a sleek look. Curly hair is the envy of gentlemen everywhere for good reason, and the mohawk fade is the perfect way to showcase your unique locks. Whether you have short or long curly hair, your natural volume will mean you can do without the high hold gel that most mohawks need, but you still won’t have as much height as some spiky hair. Consider adding a mid or high fade to your curly haircut to create the appearance of more height.

Straight hair was born to be styled into a mohawk fade. The straight hair mohawk fade is low-maintenance and versatile, allowing you to achieve many trendy men’s hairstyles. Whether you choose a low burst fade with longer hair on top or a high taper with a shorter style, your straight mohawk will stand out with a fresh cut. Simply add a strong hair product like a gel or pomade and use a comb or your fingers to style your hair upward to maximize volume and flow. If you need a more subtle look, you can easily go for a slicked back mohawk or part your hair to the side for a more conventional appearance, giving you the flexibility to be daring or dapper whenever you need it.

The mohawk fade is a cool haircut for black men who want a fashionable style. There are many black mohawk hairstyles to choose from and the right cut will complement your hair type and length. Some black men prefer the South of France haircut, which is a type of mohawk with a burst fade on the sides and back. You can also ask your barber for a temp fade with tight curls or a high top mohawk. Grow a thick beard and add a line up to enjoy a dapper look women will love.

The mohawk fade starts with short sides and often results in a v-shape in the back. The back of your mohawk haircut will depend on the type of fade you get, but the result will be a cool design that will garner attention.

The messy mohawk is a low-maintenance hairstyle for guys who prefer a relaxed look. While most men think a faded mohawk requires your hair to be spiked, but messy styles can work well with great haircuts. You’ll want to use a light styling product with a matte finish for a textured appearance that will make your hair look thick and full. This simple hairstyle will easily become one of your favorites.

The wide mohawk fade is another modern variation of an iconic punk rock hairstyle. Today’s iteration of the mohawk takes the narrow strip of long hair and widens it, almost to the natural line between the crown and the sides of the head. A wide mohawk fade is softer and more sophisticated, giving you the option to wear it up for some eye-catching spikes or wear your hair down in a more professional setting. A wide mohawk with a drop fade is one of the best all-around hairstyles appropriate for any occasion.

If you want to customize your mohawk, ask your barber to cut a v-fade for a sexy bad boy look. A faded mohawk with a v-shape in the back adds a unique twist to a popular haircut. Your tapered v-fade can drop all the way down to your neckline or you can get it shaved into the back of your head with a razor. You can take this modern style to the next level by featuring hair designs such as lines or zig-zags.

The best way to create a clean hairline is to get a mohawk with an edge up. Also known as a lineup or shape up, your barber will use a straight razor to make sharp cuts along your hairline, temples, and around your ears. After a fresh fade, an edge up will elevate your mohawk haircut with clean lines and give you that super sleek finish.

In recent years, the full mohawk has become one of the most badass haircuts as guys look to get medium length to longer styles. A full mohawk fade is characterized by a natural cut on top that continues down the back of the head, creating a look that is similar to the mullet. You can get many different types of fades on the sides and back, with the high skin fade and burst taper haircuts being the popular options. Versatile and bold, you can style your hair to the side in the office for a variation of the comb over and then spike it up when it’s time to go out and have fun.

The crew cut mohawk is a short men’s haircut that combines classic and edgy styles to create a very masculine look. Cool and fresh, the crew cut fade pairs well with a mohawk and extends the shorter hair on the top down the back of the head. Grow some stubble with your crew cut for an extra sexy touch. This mohawk cut is ideal for men who want to keep a clean look or grow out their hair and need a great style in the meantime. Keep in mind that the shorter your mohawk, the more frequently you’ll need a cut to keep it sharp.

The buzz cut fade is a modern short men’s hairstyle all around, with faded sides and short hair on top. There are many types of fade haircuts to pair with a buzzed cut. For starters, you’ll want to determine where the tapering begins so you have a choice of a high, mid or low fade. A buzz cut with a low fade begins the tapering just above the ears and stays close to the neckline in the back; whereas, the mid fade starts in the middle of the head and the high fade effectively becomes a high and tight.
Guys can further tailor the cut by requesting a taper, bald, skin, or drop fade. Ultimately, buzz cut fade haircuts are more versatile and less extreme than traditional, military-inspired hairstyles. Although it’s still very short, a fade incorporates an extra dimension because the look isn’t a uniform length all over the head. Plus, it’s an excellent choice for guys with receding hairlines or thin hair as it adds more volume by making your hair on top appear thicker.

The zero buzz cut is a short haircut that requires no guard on the clippers and cuts the hair down to the skin. Close to a shaved head, a zero haircut is an edgy style that leaves a slight shadow for a clean-cut look. With no hair to protect you, a zero cut is reserved for men with a nicely shaped head and attractive facial features.

A buzz cut with a skin fade is one of the most common haircut styles because it cuts the sides short enough to create contrast for the buzzed top. A skin fade haircut on the sides and back tapers the hair down to the skin. Guys can ask their barber for a low, medium or high bald fade and pair the faded cut with a number 1, 2, or 3 haircut on top. Trendy and charming, a skin fade buzz cut is a cool hairstyle that looks even better with some facial hair for a sexy style.

A buzz cut with a beard is a great way to balance your look while giving you a rugged style. If you want to stand out with buzzed hair and a beard, it’s important to understand how to pull this look off properly. For example, you need to keep your beard groomed and styled because, with short hair on top, more of the focus will be on your facial hair.
Men with thick hair buzz cuts can enjoy more latitude and grow a long full beard. On the other hand, guys with thin or thinning will want heavy stubble or a well-kept short beard style to draw attention away from the hairline without making the contrast overwhelmingly obvious. Paired with a trendy buzz cut fade where you taper your sideburns, a beard will add texture and dimension to your badass style.

A short buzz cut is very short and often clipped with a number 1 guard, achieving a cut close to the head. The three best examples of short buzz haircuts are the military induction cut, the burr cut, and the high and tight fade. While not quite a zero, these types of buzz cuts involve a number one all over for a close cut and a taper fade on the sides and back.
If your hairline is fuller, a military-style buzz cut is a fantastic way to bring a sharp, masculine feel to your look as the angles are crisp and edgy. Guys with thin hair want to avoid this since the dimensions bring attention to your head. Instead, you should allow for a little extra growth to soften the cut and make it more sophisticated.

The long buzz cut can take many forms, with the most popular being the crew cut mixed with buzzed hair on the sides. Great for men with the right look, a long hair buzz cut offers additional styling options that aren’t available with a shorter cut. For example, a buzz cut with longer hair on top can be styled with pomade or clay for a textured, natural look that adds volume and depth.
Alternatively, you may prefer to pair a buzz cut with a fringe, Caesar haircut, or a side swept front. A Caesar crew cut is achieved with longer buzzed hair on top using a number 4 guard and paired with a fade on the sides. You can leave the longer bangs brushed forward and hanging over the forehead or swept to the side for a very short League hairstyle.

If you want the middle ground, a medium buzz cut can be the perfect haircut that isn’t too short or long. Generally clipped with a number 3 on top and 1 or 2 on the sides, medium buzzed haircuts are tight and tapered for a sleek look. For an easy trim that won’t expose your scalp but won’t grow out too fast, start with this 3 buzz cut.

The buzz cut mohawk has a daring edge that isn’t for the faint of heart. Whether you’re a badass alpha male or just a teen bad boy, the buzzed mohawk hairstyle is the perfect look for men with short hair who want to stand out from the crowd and turn heads.
The trick is to leave a two-inch-wide patch of hair, and then buzz the rest of your head down to the skin. The contrast creates a bold aesthetic that’s as flexible as it is original. Apply gel, pomade or wax through your hair and style a mini mohawk.

The undercut buzz cut starts by buzzing the sides and back of the head to the same length and then leaving very short hair on top. Similar to a high and tight, the undercut haircut can be shorter or longer depending on the length of hair you keep on top.
For an edgy look, you can shave the sides down; otherwise, a little length can be classy, low-maintenance and versatile for professional men. Ultimately, buzzed hair with an undercut can be a great way to change up your look from the classic version of this popular hairstyle.

Get a buzz cut with bangs if you want to emulate a short crop top. Also known as a French crop or short fringe, a cropped buzz cut begins with a taper fade haircut on the sides to blend the style. The buzzed haircut on top is still very short, but the bangs in front are left a little longer for some styling flexibility. The fringe can then be brushed forward and down like a Caesar cut or swept to the side for a simple Ivy League hairstyle.

The buzz cut taper is a middle ground for men who want to keep their hair short without exposing the skin. Generally, a taper fade blends the hair on your sides and back into the scalp, while a taper haircut blends shorter but leaves some hair at the bottom. A buzz cut with a taper is a good hairstyle for professional men or guys who want a short haircut that is smooth and charming without being too edgy.
To give a taper fade with buzzed hair, your barber ends the tapering process with a #1 or #2 guard and keeps some length. The buzz cut is still trimmed short all around and will contrast with the shorter faded sides. Fresh and unique, this trend is popular because it softens your head and features, yet is still manly and clean-cut.

Buzz cut designs offer a cool way to customize your haircut. From lines to zig zags to unique shapes, hair designs add flair to a minimal buzz cut haircut. Guys can shave their favorite design ideas into the faded sides or directly into the buzzed hair on top.

The induction cut is the shortest buzz cut you can get without shaving your head down to the skin. As a military haircut, the induction buzz cut can be trimmed to the same length all around the head or paired with shaved sides. You should be comfortable with the decision beforehand as there is no going back once this no guard haircut trims your hair down to nothing.
Well-suited for all hair types, the induction haircut is particularly useful for guys with thinning hair or receding hairlines who are not ready to shave their head. Feature an edge up, heavy stubble, or a thick beard to complement the style.

The burr cut is a type of shorter buzz cut that is perfect for the men who want a very close cut style. Slightly longer than an induction cut, the burr buzz cut looks best on guys who have a full hairline and thick hair. You can cut this short hairstyle yourself at home with quality clippers and make it a uniform haircut all around the head.
If you like to get trimmed up at a barbershop, the better look is a taper fade on the sides and back with a #1 or #2 cut on top and a line up along the hairline. Stylish for young and older men alike, experiment with a burr haircut and grow a full beard for a hot, youthful aesthetic.

The butch cut is the longest buzz cut style for men and is similar to the crew cut. Also known as a brush cut, the hair on top is buzzed into place with clippers using a number 3 or 4 guard. Unlike a traditional buzz cut, the most popular variation of the butch haircut is the brush cut fade. With longer hair on top, the fade blends the sides and back of the head to taper the look and create contrast.
The back and sides gradually reduce in length as they reach the ears, creating a short-yet-dense visual. A brush cut is ideal for guys who wear an Ivy League cut as once it grows, it will transform into a standard crew cut.

A buzz cut with a line adds a level of excitement that you don’t normally get with a standard buzz cut. Without the ability to mix up lengths for a striking appeal, you can shave an edgy line into the sides of your head for a modern masculine look.
What makes this trend popular is that you can play around with the line to make sure the novelty isn’t lost. A single line can be wider and thicker if you want to get people’s attention, or it can thin if you’re trying to be subtle. Guys can even get 2 or 3 lines etched into their cut. Also, a line design works as a hard part that highlights a buzzed top and faded or undercut sides.

A buzz cut with a shape up is when your barber trims your hairline and temples to create sharp, visible lines. Also known as a line or edge up, the effect is striking as the shape up helps to clean any untidy strands or unevenness that may stick out.
Similarly, a line up uses crisp cuts to change the proportions of your face and hair, resulting in an aggressive, rugged style.

The number 1 buzz cut is the shortest haircut you can get with a guard attached to a clipper. Most closely associated with an induction cut, the #1 haircut length corresponds to leaving 1/8 inch of hair, producing very short hair with no styling requirements.
If you want a 1 buzz cut all over, you can skip the barbershop and just cut your own hair at home with clippers. For guys who want some contrast, ask your barber for a #1 on top but with faded sides. To maintain this cut and keep it fresh, you’ll need a haircut regularly.

The number 2 buzz cut leaves your hair longer and allows you to style your short hair, but the haircut is still very buzzed and easy to do. Also known as a burr cut, the number 2 haircut length will cut your hair at 1/4 inch, keeping just enough hair to cover our scalp and minimize visibility.
Guys can use a #2 guard all over the head or stick to a #2 on top with a #1 or skin fade on the sides and back. Combined with a clean hairline, well-groomed facial hair and textured styling, this handsome hairstyle is sleek and smooth.

The number 3 buzz cut keeps the length on top at 3/8 inch and is a common haircut given that it is the foundation for the classic 3-2-1 buzzed hairstyle. Also known as a brush or butch cut, a #3 guard on top with a #2 on the sides and back creates just the right level of contrast and style.
Alternatively, some men want a regular haircut with a number 3 or 4 all around. Even and uniform, this longer buzzed hairstyle looks better with a square head shape and a clean shaven face or a little stubble.

As one of the most popular haircuts for black men, the buzz cut continues to be a trendy style. Whether you want a brush cut fade or a very short haircut to style into waves, a buzz cut for black men delivers a clean, fresh look. For a refined stylish hairstyle that will turn heads, guys should pair buzzed black hair with a temp fade, line up and short beard.

The buzz cut is a hot trend for Asian men who prefer short hair. From an induction cut to a burr, butch and crew cut, the Asian buzz cut allows you to explore a range of styles and lengths. Because Asian hair is typically thick and straight, it’s naturally suited for a cool buzzed hairstyle. Start with a fade or undercut on the sides and short trimmed top, and then let the hair grow out with time to style different looks.

The white guy buzz cut is crazy cool and minimalist, especially when it is trimmed and styled properly. Despite the short hair, men can get creative with their buzzed haircuts. Whether you shave the sides, grow a full beard, dye your hair blonde, or experiment with different cuts, there are many ways for white men to wear a buzz cut.

The buzz cut is a natural haircut for boys, especially in the spring and summer time. Whether you’re tired of styling your little boys hair for school or just want a simple haircut you can give him at home, a kids buzz cut might be the right hairstyle for your little boy. Cool, cute and low-maintenance, just make sure the sides are shorter than the buzzed hair on top for a defined, trendy look.

Titre: 45 Best Hairstyles For A Receding Hairline
Description: The undercut is one of the best ways to balance out a receding hairline. Undercut hairstyles for men have been popular and trendy in recent years. The undercut requires short back and sides, making it great for hiding thinning hair and men’s receding hairlines. Plus, the short haircut on the sides complements a number of sexy styles, including the slicked back, comb over and quiff. If you want a versatile short sides, long top haircut, start with this edgy, modern look.

Titre: 45 Best Hairstyles For A Receding Hairline
Description:
Taper fade haircut is another classy and stylish look that works for men with receding hairlines. With so many different types of fades, guys have the opportunity to really tailor their cut. For example, for guys who are balding, we would recommend a skin fade or high fade that blends directly into the high hairline.
By starting high and tapering the length very short with clippers, a faded hairline can draw attention away from your bald spots and towards the fuller, longer hair on top.

Titre: 45 Best Hairstyles For A Receding Hairline
Description:
Short haircuts generally work better with receding hairlines. The type of short hair you get with a high and tight, buzz cut, crew cut, or crop top will help people avoid noticing that some parts of your head have hair and others don’t. By keeping your hair short and trimmed, others won’t be able to compare your receding hairline with the hair on top.
The other advantage is that men’s short haircuts are clean, easy to get, and simple to style. If you plan on applying a styling product, just make sure to use a clay or wax to give your strands a thick look. However, remember to not apply too much product on thinning. Clumping your hairs can leave gaps and expose the scalp, giving off the appearance that you are balding in other areas.

Titre: 45 Best Hairstyles For A Receding Hairline
Description:
If you have long hair and want to keep it, there are ways for men with receding hairlines to make long hair look good. Nowadays, the hottest long men’s hairstyles are the man bun, male ponytail, and free-flowing natural hair. In fact, the man bun fade offers the best of both worlds – short sides and back, and a long top that is pulled back.
If you plan on styling your long hair, just apply a light hold, no shine wax, clay or cream for a bit of texture and control. Nevertheless, it is important to note that guys with thin or fine hair shouldn’t style a long look. Using long thin hair on top will not distract people from your deep hairline, but actually compound the problem.

Titre: 45 Best Hairstyles For A Receding Hairline
Description: Medium-length hairstyles offer the best balance between long and short hair for a receding hairline. A medium length of hair on top allows guys to style a comb over, quiff, pompadour, faux hawk, brush back, and a variety of other cool styles. Not only are these some of the most fashionable haircuts for men right now, but these cuts combine perfectly with faded sides.

Titre: 45 Best Hairstyles For A Receding Hairline
Description:
The buzz cut is among the most common receding hairline haircuts because it’s simple and easy to try. While the buzz cut can be very different and a huge change for guys who are used to having a full head of hair, the style does tone down the hairline significantly.
As a masculine and attractive cut, we highly recommend the look for all guys – White, Black, Hispanic, and Asian.

Titre: 45 Best Hairstyles For A Receding Hairline
Description:
The crew cut is another great option for making a receding hairline less noticeable. If a buzz cut is too short, the crew cut hairstyle may be a better fit, especially for business professionals who don’t want to expose their scalp in the office.
Similarly, an extension of the crew cut would be the Ivy League, which is generally a longer crew cut with a side swept front. These classic haircuts for men can be cut more traditionally, or trimmed with a fade on the sides for a modern variation.

Titre: 45 Best Hairstyles For A Receding Hairline
Description:
The comb over hairstyle is shaping up to be a barbershop favorite, whether guys are balding or not. In fact, the comb over fade can be the perfect haircut if you have full, thick hair because you can part your hair to one side and hide your receding hairline as you brush the style over.
However, it is critical to mention that the comb over haircut should not be worn by men with thin hair. Parting your hair when you are thinning on top is a recipe for disaster, and guys should just wait to grow their hair out longer or get a shorter cut.

Titre: 45 Best Hairstyles For A Receding Hairline
Description:
The slick back is a sexy retro hairstyle that will play to your thinning or receding hair. Specifically, the slick back undercut and slick back fade are modern versions that are easy to get, quick to style, and universally handsome.
Just ask your barber for the slicked back hairstyle and make sure to use a strong pomade or wax when combing your hair back. Depending on the type of styling product you apply, guys can even choose between a textured brush back and a slick, shiny finish.

Titre: 45 Best Hairstyles For A Receding Hairline
Description: The mohawk features shaved sides, which means it will stop people from seeing your receding hairline. Although a short mohawk is more socially accepted, the style can work with short, medium or long hair on top. As long as you get a mohawk with trimmed sides, you can customize the shape, width and height of the hair on top any way you want. Ultimately, the signature strip in the middle that comprises the mohawk hairstyle is perfect for guys who are balding, thinning or suffering from receding hair.

Titre: 45 Best Hairstyles For A Receding Hairline
Description: The faux hawk is an excellent substitute for men who don’t want to shave the hair on their sides and back. Instead, the faux hawk fade takes advantage of the short faded hairline with a less drastic approach. By pushing your hair towards the center, drawing attention to the unique style on top, and minimizing the contrast on the sides, the fohawk haircut will make your receding hairline disappear.

Titre: 45 Best Hairstyles For A Receding Hairline
Nom: Long Hair on Top + Short Faded Sides

Haircut Names For Men – Types of Haircuts
Description: The fade is a men’s haircut where the hair on the sides and back of your head gradually get shorter from top to bottom. The process of fading from one length to another is generally achieved using hair clippers. Because the fade comes in a variety of styles, it is important to tell your barber the type of fade haircut you want. You can choose a low, mid or high fade to determine where the cut is tapered. You can also decide how short to fade the cut by asking for a bald fade, which will blend your hair into your skin.

Titre: Haircut Names For Men – Types of Haircuts
Description: Also known as a taper, the taper fade is a clean-cut modern haircut that continues to be popular in barbershops. The main difference between the taper and fade is that the fade cut is blended into the skin while the taper leaves very short hair. The taper is an incredibly chic and classy look that any man can get to elevate his appearance.

Titre: Haircut Names For Men – Types of Haircuts
Description: The low fade features a more even and gradual blend between the short hair around the ears and the longer hair near the crown than other taper or fade haircuts. The low fade is more subtle than some of the other fade options but no less stylish by any means. As with any fade, you’ll want regular cuts to maintain the clean look. The low fade pairs exceptionally well with some stubble or a short beard.

Titre: Haircut Names For Men – Types of Haircuts
Description: The high fade is a type of fade that features a more sudden contrast between the longer top and shorter sides. The high fade haircut starts near the top of the sides and back and quickly tapers down. Bold and edgy, this faded cut offers very short hair for a fresh look.

Titre: Haircut Names For Men – Types of Haircuts
Description: The mid fade strikes the perfect balance between a high and low fade, creating a bold yet effortlessly cool look. A mid fade haircut is a cut that starts in the middle of the head and tapers down to the ears and neckline. This medium fade gradually blends the short sides and back into the longer hair, and can be the ideal complement to a stylish business professional hairstyle. You can ask your barber for a mid bald fade for an edgy finish. If you’re looking to take the first steps into a more trendy haircut, then the mid cut fade would be a great choice.

Titre: Haircut Names For Men – Types of Haircuts
Description: The skin fade is a very short haircut style that requires cutting hair shorter down the sides and back, and gradually blending the cut into the skin. Also known as a bald fade, this type of fade haircut is an edgy and bold look that needs regular visits to the barber to maintain. You can combine the bald fade haircut with trendy hairstyles to create a stylish look. Whether you want a high, mid or low skin fade, talk to your barber about adding this feature to your cut.

Titre: Haircut Names For Men – Types of Haircuts
Description: The undercut is a very popular modern haircut where the sides and back are clipped short or shaved. Traditionally, the undercut haircut features a full disconnect and is not faded, and the hair on top is left much longer. Some guys will ask their barber to taper the cut to create an undercut fade. The undercut can be combined with a range of men’s hairstyles to create a trendy look. The hair on top can be combed over, swept to the side, slicked back, brushed up, styled into a pompadour, or made to get a quiff. Ultimately, the undercut is one of the coolest “short on the sides, long on the top” haircuts you can have these days.

Titre: Haircut Names For Men – Types of Haircuts
Description: The disconnected undercut features a sharp contrast between the long hair on top and shorter sides rather than the gradual blending of a taper or fade. As a cool hairstyle for guys, the disconnected undercut is both bold and handsome. The contrast will be beneficial for men with round or oval face shapes to add some angular features, but every guy can achieve this cut.

Titre: Haircut Names For Men – Types of Haircuts
Description: The pompadour is a timeless men’s hairstyle that features longer hair in the front with short hair on the sides and back. Classy and handsome, the pompadour involves the hair being styled up and back away from the forehead, showing off your hair with some volume. Pompadour styles are ideal for guys with thick, straight, or wavy hair. Because volume is essential to the look, use a product with a high hold like a pomade, putty, or gel to make sure your hair stays put throughout the day.

Titre: Haircut Names For Men – Types of Haircuts

Coupled with a fade cut on the sides, the quiff haircut is versatile and trendy for guys with all hair types.

Titre: Haircut Names For Men – Types of Haircuts

Titre: Haircut Names For Men – Types of Haircuts

Men with fine and straight hair textures will find the most success with the slick back hairstyle. Slicked back hair remains one of the coolest modern men’s hairstyles to get right now.

Titre: Haircut Names For Men – Types of Haircuts

Titre: Haircut Names For Men – Types of Haircuts

Description: The side part is a classic hairstyle that is timeless and professional for men. Short box braids are great if you have short hair and want a fashionable yet edgy hairstyle. Without growing your hair out or getting extensions, short styles are achieved by creating the traditional square shapes before braiding the hair on top.

Whether you have hair long enough to braid or you want to add synthetic hair to get your desired length, braids with long hair are flattering for most face shapes. Long box braids hairstyles can be layered, let down, pulled back, or tied up in a ponytail or bun on top of the head.

Classic and stylish, single braids work well for men who like to maintain a clean look. Also known as individual braids, this handsome look is minimal and casual, meaning you’ll only need a few minutes to change up your locks.
Single braids work well on long and short hair lengths, and are great for men and boys alike. Styled loose and hanging down the sides of the head, this fresh style continues to be on-trend in barbershops around the world.

The most popular way to get this hairstyle is to pair box braids with a fade. Men can choose from all the best types of fades, including low, mid, high, bald, drop, temp and taper fade haircuts.
With short faded hair on the sides, guys can focus the attention on their plaits. Bold and sleek, a fade with braids can take your style to the next level.

Rugged and hot, an undercut with box braids can be a stylish alternative to the fade. Short and cut to one-length on the sides and back, the undercut haircut can be buzzed or shaved down to contrast with your cool braids.
Combined with any length of hair and a number of box braids styles, the finished hairstyle is smooth and flawless. Pull your braids back into a ponytail or tie a bun up top, the look is universally flattering.

High top box braids stand out in any crowd and can be styled in a variety of ways. Popular and classy, high top braids can range in styling, from sectioned to spider braids, each offering their own textured design.
Ultimately, high top braids are fashionable and unique, so work with your stylist to determine which look is best for you.

Box braids with straight hair have been one of the most traditional hairstyle ideas around. Braiding straight hair on men is much more straightforward than dealing with kinky or curly hair.
When choosing this look, the hair is sectioned into straight lines of squares as opposed to the patterned lines used in other braided styles.

Flat top braids can be pulled into an updo or swept off to the side, depending on your preference and favorite hairstyle. All you need to do is invest in some quality elastics and you’ll have the ability to transform your box braided hair in a few simple steps.

For a modern twist, get box braids with designs and your haircut will instantly transform. Hair designs require a skilled and talented stylist with creativity. Braid designs can include 2, 3 or 4 lines with zig zags and unique braiding.

When you have longer hair, style your box braids into a ponytail for a classy look. Medium and long braids look exceptional when pulled back into a low or a high ponytail.
Masculine and attractive, this is an easy way to get your hair out of your face while you’re working. Plus, it breaks the monotony of styling your hair the same way every day.

Small box braids are thin plaits that can be styled loose, in buns or ponytails. Unlike big and jumbo braids, tiny braids are set in small squared-off sections. The smaller size means guys can ask for 3 or 4 rows of box braids on the top of their head.

Box braids have traditionally been a cool hairstyle for black men and women. Whether you’re rocking short, medium, or long braids, black guys can play around with their braided hair to find the best styles for their personal look.
Most guys start with a fade, undercut or shaved sides. There are many ways to wear box braids so find a fashionable style that works for you.

White men experimenting with box braids is a more recent trend, but this style can be adopted if you’ve got the right stylists and type of hair. White guy braid styles depend on length and design, but the sectioning technique is the same.
Tell your barber and stylist how to cut the sides and back, then decide on a length, and you’re set. Just make sure you can pull off box braids as a white boy before trying the hairstyle.

Box braids are cute and trendy for boys, making this hairstyle barbershop favorites with kids. Little boys naturally like to emulate the styles of their dads and brothers, and braids styles on boys always look good.
For one, braided hair is low-maintenance and easy to style, which means your son will spend minimal time getting ready for school. Similarly, braids can be left hanging loosely, pulled back and tied up, or swept into a ponytail when your boys are playing sports or finishing schoolwork. Description:
This classic comb over fade combines a deep side part with a low fade that is professional enough for a day at work but just edgy enough for a night out on the town. Thanks to the medium length hair on top, there are several unique ways to style this cut, and maintaining it is a breeze.

Also known as a bald fade, this skin fade comb over is cut super short on the sides with a hard part to accentuate the brush over. This modern comb over hairstyle starts with a high bald fade to highlight the styling above. The barber shaved in a parted line to emphasize the side part.

This short comb over fade looks great and styles easy, especially for guys who want one of the coolest short haircuts for men. The taper fade comb over can be a good professional hairstyle . While the comb over taper is generally more conservative, it can still be incredibly stylish and fashion for young men. The side part fade, often referred to as the side part comb over fade, is the blending of these classic gentleman haircuts. With a hard side part hairstyle on top and a skin faded cut on the sides and back, this styling was made for the modern man.
You may be wondering how the side part comb over is any different than just a comb over or side part. Generally, the side part haircut is styled flat and swept straight over to one side.

For thick or curly hair, you’ll want a strong hold; for guys with thinning hair, we recommend something that thickens the strands; and finally, for men with wavy or long hair, use styling product that emphasizes your natural texture.

The burst fade makes this comb over pompadour really stand out. As one of the best comb over fade styles, the hard part creates an air of modern styling and the pompadour adds some retro flair. This comb over cut is ideal for men who have thick straight or wavy hair.

This faded comb over haircut is a badass cut and style thanks to the sharp line up and the high skin undercut fade. The high skin fade haircut is trimmed close to the top for plenty of contrast, and the comb over is brushed up and to the side for extra volume. With thick hair, use a strong pomade or wax to style the perfect comb over hairstyle.

The undercut hairstyle continues to be popular with men of all ages, and this undercut comb over haircut is a great choice for any guy looking for something easy to style and maintain. With three to four inches of length on top and sides buzzed nearly to the skin, all you need is a set of trimmers and some medium-hold pomade for your daily routine.
As one of the best textured hairstyles for guys, this sexy comb over with shaved sides is trendy and casual.

Nom: Short Comb Over with Hard Part and High Fade
Description:
For a more classic look that is reminiscent of the 50s and early 60s, this short comb over with a hard part is a great idea for men who want a shorter haircut to style. Paired with a high fade on the sides and a thick shaved part, this style offers a stylish comb over side part that is classy and chic.
A good hair styling product makes this look easy to get for business professionals, older men, hipsters, and fuckboys alike.

Nom: Comb Over with Shaved Sides and Line
Description:
Comb over hairstyles and shape up cuts pair nicely, which is evident with this awesome style. With a thick shaved part prominently cut into the side of the head and slightly longer hair on top, this cool men’s haircut stands out in any room.
Use a matte pomade for a textured, natural finish or a strong wax to style a faux hawk or spiky hair. Guys can also brush back their hair for a short slick back.

Nom: Hard Part Comb Over + Bald Fade + Line Up
Description: This hard part comb over with a bald fade is a fresh barbershop haircut for men. While the comb over fade remains a very popular short sides, long top hair trend, the bold line and edge up offer sharp trims that make this cut a fashion-forward look.

Nom: Long Hair Comb Over + Undercut + Beard
Description:
Men who have longer hair will love this long hair comb over hairstyle with a clearly defined, perfectly groomed beard. The hair on top is about six inches in length while the hair underneath is buzzed close to the scalp for a high-contrast finish.
The full beard is kept short, and the handlebar mustache certainly makes a statement. As a sexy modern hairstyle for men, we highly recommend the styling – just make sure you use good hair products and a beard grooming kit for an effortless look.

Nom: Disconnected Undercut + Long Comb Over + Full Beard
Description:
As a popular haircut style for men with longer, thicker hair, this disconnected undercut with a long comb over gets its name from the hard part between the short and long sections of hair. The full beard simply adds a masculine, hot look for guys who can grow nice facial hair.
This long comb over hairstyle requires thick hair with volume, movement and flow. To achieve this cool look, make sure to use a high-quality shampoo and conditioner for your hair type along with a texturizing pomade, clay or cream.

The classic thick comb over fade gets a reboot with this haircut; the medium-length hair is swept over and parted to provide a cool blonde hairstyle women will find irresistible.
The longer hair on top gives you plenty of styling power in terms of creating a quiff, pompadour, or numerous textured looks. Lastly, the manly heavy stubble beard helps to balance the height for a hot look.

Nom: High Fade + Wavy Hair Comb Over + Part
Description:
If you have naturally curly or wavy hair, this high fade wavy comb over with a deep part is a good haircut for you. Whether your hair is thick or thin, the high fade gives the appearance of more volume on top by creating contrast that focuses your attention on the styling above.
The wavy hairstyle then creates a unique texture only guys with this hair type can pull off. Using a matte pomade, clay or low-shine wax will help you style any number of trendy cuts.

Nom: Bald Fade Comb Over + Part + Thick Beard
Description: The bald fade comb over always looks good with a manly, thick beard. As the short hair on the sides and back gradually tapers down to the skin, it gives the longer hair on top the appearance of being fuller with more volume. The best full beard styles offer guys a masculine, rugged look.

The textured comb over hairstyle is all the rage right now, and this natural side swept look with a taper fade is a unique way to get it. The layered comb over is brushed to one side while the hair on the sides is cut very short. Use a cream or clay styling product to give your hair textured and style.

Nom: Mid Fade Comb Over + Hard Part
Description:
This mid fade comb over with a shape up and hard part makes for an awesome fuckboy haircut. The styling mixes in a pompadour or slick back for the perfect balance between professional and playful.
If your hair is naturally thick and straight, you will be hard-pressed to find a sexy hairstyle that looks hotter than this one. Whether you want a college frat boy haircut or a classic young professional style, this cut works.

Nom: Textured Spiky Comb Over + Bald Fade
Description: This spiky comb over fade affords you the opportunity to be unique. Spiked hair is a hot men’s hair trend right now, and when paired with the bald fade, it looks incredibly clean cut and fresh. Styling is relatively simple with strong pomade or clay, a natural-bristle brush, and blow dryer to ensure every hair is in place and stays that way all day.

Nom: Hard Side Part + Low Skin Fade
Description:
If you want some height and a style that looks perfectly coiffed every single day, the hard side part with a low skin fade is an excellent choice. For a retro twist, this example incorporates a small pomp in the front.
All you need to style it is a volumizing hair product that won’t weigh down your hair. The best part is this cool hairstyle works well for men with thick or thin hair. Even guys with receding hairlines will appreciate this classic styling.

Nom: Taper Fade Comb Over + Line in Hair
Description: Here, you see a thick comb over with a prominent shaved part separating the taper fade and the long hair on top. This long comb over style is ideal for boys who want to get the coolest hairstyles for teenagers. Similarly, young guys can wear the look for everything, from a formal event like a wedding to a college party.

Nom: Low Drop Fade + Comb Over + Side Swept Fringe
Description:
The side swept fringe completes makes this comb over hairstyle. While sweeping the hair to create that wavy finish may add some additional effort to your styling routine, the final look is worth the investment in time.
This style is an excellent choice for men who have naturally wavy hair. Wavy hairstyles, when tapered and textured, is also quite voluminous. The low drop fade on the sides and back also adds a fresh touch.

Nom: Long Textured Comb Over + Short Sides
Description:
Though many of the comb over haircuts you’ll see here rely on buzzed fades, this taper fade is a little different. Here, the idea involves pairing the long textured comb over with short sides that blend only slightly just above the ears.
This is an easy look to maintain, and with a bit of matte hair product, the brushed up style will stay in place for hours. Plus, the short beard is nicely trimmed and maintained, adding a classy element.

Nom: Short Slick Comb Over + Low Bald Fade + Beard
Description:
