The wolf cut is a fashionable style for guys who keep their hair longer and prefer messy, full-bodied looks. The short choppy layers on top complement the longer layers on the sides to imitate the mane of a wolf. Attractive and fun, this haircut is a modern variation of a classic style that will get you noticed.

The full mop top is the exact cut you want if you are looking for ease. While this cut brings out youthful features, men of any age can try it out for themselves. The mop is enhanced with layers that help give it a unique flow.

The fluffy Edgar is a popular haircut style for the modern day skater who values fullness and volume. The curly hair on top is left loose and textured. To get this look, you can ask your barber for a taper fade on the sides and back or maintain a low-cropped cut to create a thicker look.

Paired with short sides, tousled curls are an irresistible look for young skaters who want to achieve bounce and movement for a sexy look. By keeping the sides short, you will allow your naturally curly hair to appear light and energetic. Use mousse to give it the classic tousled finish.

The high and tight fade is a modern style that blends the sides and back into the longer hair on top to create a stylish look. The high and tight fade haircut offers a softer style with subtle contrast that can work well for every occasion. While the high fade is the most popular cut, you can ask your barber to experiment with a low or mid taper fade. To tailor the look further, you can feature a skin, drop, bald, burst or razor fade that adds a fresh dimension to the cut. The faded variation provides a sleek and low-maintenance look that will elevate your style.

The high and tight skin fade is an edgy haircut that comes with very short hair on the sides and back to accentuate the longer styling on top. A skin fade haircut can be used to personalize your look and create a military style without shaving your sides. As one of the most popular types of fades to get, this faded cut will start high and blend the hair into the scalp for a bold look. If you’re looking to level up your style, the high and tight with a skin fade might be the perfect cut.

The high and tight undercut can be a cool hairstyle for when you want to transform your look. The undercut is a short haircut that proves a sharp contrast between the buzzed sides and longer hair on top. While fades are tapered, the undercut features hair that is all one-length and will make your style softer and more textured. The undercut proves that the high and tight haircut with no fade can still look fashionable and ruggedly handsome.

The high and tight bald fade is a sharp haircut that blends the sides and back into the skin for a daring finish. Also known as a skin fade, the bald fade provides a high-contrast cut that looks great with short and long styles. Men with thin or thinning hair may want to consider this faded finish since it can hide a receding hairline. If you want a Jarhead haircut and don’t want to shave your sides, this high and tight fade might be an appropriate choice for a fresh look.

The modern high and tight is a versatile cut that offers trendy styling options for a flattering look. This modern haircut comes with tapered sides and slightly longer hair on top that can be styled messy, spiky or combed over. Easy to style and always charming, you can transform this classic look into a cool hairstyle for the modern gentleman.

The high and tight buzz cut is a short hairstyle that offers a functional and masculine look. A buzzed haircut is a military style that pairs naturally with the high and tight by simply dictating that the top be cut short. Suited for straight, thick, wavy or curly hair, this short cropped look offers a unique take on the classic buzz cut.

The long high and tight is a stylish haircut that offers a short cut on the sides and back with longer hair on top for more styling options. The long top high and tight can be achieved with a taper fade or undercut to create the necessary contrast and complement the extra length. This versatile longer style can be swept to the side, brushed back, spiked up or combed forward to suit your needs. For a textured look, use a strong hair product like pomade or wax with a matte finish to give the style volume and fullness.

The short high and tight is a simple haircut that offers a striking look that requires no styling. This masculine style comes with short hair on the sides, back and top to create a sleek cut. When talking to your barber, you’ll want to ask for a number 0, 1 or 2 on the sides and a 3, 4, 5 or 6 on top. This very short style is ideal for guys with thick hair who won’t expose their scalp with a close-cropped cut. Invest in high-quality clippers to get this look at home and save money.

The military high and tight is a cool haircut that is low-maintenance and practical for men who really want short hair. This military hairstyle features a high skin fade on the sides and back with a short crop top for an edgy finish. This popular short cut is great for curly, wavy and straight thick hair that needs a trim for easier styling. Take the military high and tight style to the next level with clean-shaven sides.

The high and tight comb over is a business professional look that offers a dapper finish for a work-appropriate style. The comb over haircut has become one of the most popular styles for guys who want a versatile and fashionable appearance. With a fade or undercut on the sides and back, the longer hair on top can be combed to the side for a clean parted finish. Similar to the gentleman’s side part, use a quality styling product to keep your hair in place all day.

The high and tight crew cut is a classic style for guys who want a masculine look with slightly longer hair on top than a buzz cut. The modern crew cut often features a low, mid or high fade haircut on the sides and back. This simple tapered hairstyle offers a clean-cut look that works nicely all around.

The high and tight recon is an extreme military haircut that requires shaved sides and very short hair on top for an edgy look. The recon hairstyle leaves a small patch on the top of the head, creating a disconnected look higher up that can resemble a mohawk. For the clean-shaven sides and back, your barber will use clippers with no guard or a foil shaver. Popular with Recon Marines, this badass cut is not for the fainthearted.

Nom: High and Tight Fade with Hard Part
Description: The high and tight fade with a hard part is a unique look that can add visual interest to your haircut. The hard part is a thick shaved line that creates a sharp style where your hair can be distinctly parted. If you’re looking to design a cool cut, the hard side part can be an excellent addition.

The low and tight is a classy haircut for guys who want a fashionable and relaxed style. The low and tight hairstyle features a low fade on the sides and back for a more conservative and elegant look. By exposing less of the scalp, the low taper fade produces a versatile cut that’s universally flattering and work-appropriate.

The high and tight with a beard is a sexy look that will accentuate this edgy cut for a handsome touch. The high and tight haircut can be partnered with a beard to sport another dimension to the style, balancing out the look and amplifying the alpha male vibe. Some guys may want to style a short beard for a kept look while others may try to grow out longer facial hair for extra flair.

A number 1 on the sides is a short haircut where the sides and back are buzzed with clippers down to 1/8 inch. With a 2, 3 or 4 haircut on top, the 1 on the sides creates the foundation that highlights the styling above. As a type of buzz cut, this clipper guard size can be used to get a low-maintenance cut that is always easy to style.

Nom: Number 2, 3 or 4 on Top with 2 on the Sides
Description: A number 2 on the sides is a classic men’s haircut where the sides and back are buzzed down to 1/4 inch and the hair on top is cut longer with a number 2, 3 or 4 clipper guard. When visiting a barbershop, the best way to get the haircut you want is to tell your barber the numbers you would like used. The 2 on the sides is short without exposing the scalp, offering a regular cut that works well for most guys. For a longer style, you can ask your stylist to give you a number 5, 6, 7 or 8 haircut that will leave you up to an inch on top.

David Beckham’s short hair is a stylish look that took center stage for much of his soccer career, highlighting his rugged and masculine style. These short hairstyles have been low-maintenance and refreshing with a shorter cut on the sides and longer hair on top. With strong facial features, the footballer has rocked everything from a military buzz cut to a daring undercut with a comb over.
To keep up with his fashionable wife Victoria Beckham, his style never look unkempt. Instead, he maintains a uniform length with regular trims for a sleek and cool look. For an effortlessly sexy appearance on and off the pitch, David Beckham invests in a high-quality wax, pomade or styling cream to create natural texture and movement.

David Beckham’s long hair is a versatile and trendy style that has been synonymous with the star’s playful energy and youthful look. During his younger years, Beckham’s longer hairstyles were often styled with shoulder-length hair that was left loose or tied up into a loose ponytail or man bun. Medium to longer hair can be a challenge to style and maintain but can give guys a hot vibe. To recreate his flowing long styles, you’ll need to grow your hair out and add light layers for definition.
Long styles work best on straight hair as it lies flat, but you can attempt these styles on wavy or curly hair for a bolder look. You’ll want to wash your hair with a quality shampoo and conditioner to add moisturize and fullness to your look. When styling, consider a light hair clay or cream with a matte finish for a textured effect.

The David Beckham undercut is an edgy haircut style that creates the contrast necessary to style a bold look with the longer hair on top. While there are different types of cuts, the disconnected undercut has been Beckham’s favorite style. This popular cut features longer hair on top with a sharp transition on the sides and back for a modern look. Beckham likes to style a slicked back undercut with a textured finish, but the cut works with many different hairstyles. Great with a comb over or quiff, this stylish haircut can look classy and subtle or casually chic and fun.

The David Beckham fade is a short haircut that offers a low-maintenance and cool look for guys who want a modern cut. The fade haircut features tapered hair on the sides and back with longer hair on top, resulting in a trendy style that pairs perfectly with all the most popular men’s hairstyles. You can choose a low, mid or high fade and ask your barber to taper the cut into the skin for a clean finish.

The comb over is a classic style for guys who favor a timeless, fashionable appearance. David Beckham’s comb over makes the most of his thick hair and he often wears it slicked back or combed into a gentle side part for an elegant, formal look. He builds volume and texture in the crown with a strong wax or pomade for events but will blow dry his hair and fix it with a light hairspray for casual days. To keep all hairs in place, check your hair carefully in the mirror and slick down any cowlicks by brushing hair in the direction of growth.

The David Beckham buzz cut is a military-inspired style that looks ruggedly handsome with no styling necessary. Buzzed haircuts are short and low-maintenance, making them great styles for athletes. During his career, Beckham has rocked everything from an extremely short buzz cut to longer variations like the crew cut. To achieve this look, ask your barber to use clippers with a number 1, 2 or 3 guard. For a softer look, consider a longer style with a skin fade haircut on the sides and back. Guys can choose between an even length all over or a tapered cut that creates contrast.

The David Beckham quiff is an excellent hairstyle for guys who want a timeless look with volume and style. Stylish with a fade or undercut on the sides, Beckham typically keeps his hair short to medium length when styling a quiff. To get an elegant look, ask your barber for a classic taper haircut with extra length on top. Experiment with a bald fade for an edgy finish that blends the sides into the scalp. Using a matte styling wax or light-hold pomade will give your hair texture without weighing it down for a dapper look.

The David Beckham faux hawk is a daring hairstyle that the famous soccer player rocked in his younger days and spoke to his punkish, playful side. While he got into more sophisticated cuts later, this spiky style contributed to Beckham becoming a fashion icon. As a less-extreme mohawk, the faux hawk haircut features short shaved sides and longer hair on top that is spiked up towards the middle of the head. To recreate this trendy look, use a strong pomade or wax and spike your hair in different directions.

The David Beckham pompadour is an elegant hairstyle that offers versatility and height for a cool look. The pomp can be worn tousled and spiked for a disheveled look or slicked back for a fashionable style that’s ideal for professional settings. The front and middle of the hair are typically kept long, but the sides can be tapered to add contrast and depth. Keep the lines neat for a timeless look that’s always on-trend.

The David Beckham mohawk is an edgy and extreme haircut that put the soccer player on the map as a guy willing to push boundaries. He began his soccer career with shorter styles but began to switch things up by pushing his hair upward and rocking a shorter back and sides. To get a mohawk that won’t look severe, avoid shaving your sides and ask your barber for an undercut or taper faded haircut.

The David Beckham mullet is a retro hairstyle with a modern twist that worked to look stylish and cool. The style features tight sides and relatively short hair at the front and longer hair at the back. Beckham makes this cut look good by keeping the difference between the back and the sides less pronounced. This gives him a relaxed style that looks fresh and put together without giving him a country vibe. He uses styling creams and waxes to lightly push the hair back and visits his barbers for regular trims to avoid looking scruffy.

The David Beckham crew cut is a charming haircut that looks preppy and handsome on guys who need a low-maintenance professional style. The crew cut has been a fashionable look for years and continues to be a popular trend. Beckham frequently sported this Ivy League style during his football days as it allowed him to look good on the pitch without affecting his gameplay. To add dimension to your style, consider pairing your crew cut with a classic fade for a sophisticated vibe. For a rugged casual appearance, grow light stubble or a full beard.

David Beckham frequently made waves in the fashion industry with his messy hair. Although he typically looks polished and put-together, Beckham’s layered locks and messy bangs turned him into an attractive bad boy. To get his rebellious style, ask your barber for choppy bangs and layers. You’ll need decent length and volume to work with, so be prepared to grow out your hair for a few months before trying this look. For more texture, use a styling wax or pomade and pull your hair into different directions for a disheveled bedhead vibe.

The David Beckham cornrows is an iconic style that remains as one of the footballer’s most memorable looks. These types of braided hairstyles look best on black men who want a protective low-maintenance look. There are many different cornrow styles for guys to consider so make sure to visit a barber that specializes in black hair for assistance.

David Beckham’s short spiky hairstyle has become one of his most popular looks, offering a bad boy style that complements light facial hair. With a taper haircut on the sides and back, spiky hair can look clean and universally flattering for guys who want a cool business professional cut.

The Thomas Shelby haircut is a cool short style that features an undercut on the sides and back with a longer French crop on top. Played by Cillian Murphy, Tommy Shelby is a crime boss with a stylish short haircut that looks masculine and edgy. The actor’s cut reflects his edgy, criminal lifestyle. While his classic undercut does not require any tapering, modern gentlemen may choose a fade to complement their disconnected style. For a tapered finish, you’ll want to ask your barber for an undercut fade that balances these awesome haircuts.
The sharp, shaved lines of this cut imitate the traditional style worn by street gangs in the late 1800s and early 1900s. While Tommy Shelby has short hair, there is extra length left in the front to style a sweeping fringe. The layered cut is left textured and loose, fitting beneath a newsboy cap. This angular cut works best on guys with longer oval face shapes and strong jawlines. If you have a square or round face, ask your barber to assess your proportions to create a variation of the cut that works for you.
Cillian Murphy’s Peaky Blinders haircut was largely inspired by modern hair trends rather than actual styles of 1920’s England, the setting of the show. If you’re trying to get Tommy Shelby’s hairstyle from the show, your local barber should be able to cut and style this look with easy. Men with short hair will need to grow it out before taking the plunge since this cut requires 2 to 3 inches of length to look good. You’ll need to ask for a number 1, 2 or 3 clipper guard on the sides and back for a short undercut haircut. The longer hair on top should be cropped and layered for a stylish finish. When styling the look, you’ll need a hair dryer and a light to medium hold hair product such as pomade, wax or clay for a natural matte finish.

The Arthur Shelby haircut is an edgy style where the sides and back are cut very short and the hair on top is left longer to create a slicked back undercut. For a modern twist, you can ask your barber for a high skin fade or shaved haircut on the back and sides. Played by Paul Anderson, Arthur Shelby has a longer style that offers a high-contrast look with a free-flowing finish that makes a bold fashion statement.
Great for rebellious guys and bad boys, this striking haircut is daring and casually cool but can offer a classy vibe for the right occasions. While Tom’s hair is swept forward, Arthur’s hairstyle is brushed back with a light shine for a clean finish. To pull off the cut, you’ll require 5 to 6 inches of length on top.
To get the Arthur Shelby haircut, ask your barber for a very short disconnected undercut on the back and sides with medium length to longer hair on top. Guys can choose to shave the sides or get a razor fade to take the cut to the next level.
When styling, use a hot blow dryer and a round brush or comb to gently work the hair back. When it comes to hair products, you’ll want a light-hold styling cream or wax with a matte finish for a textured look. For a more structured look, consider a strong pomade with a low shine to get a brushed back hairstyle that will stand out. Use a small amount of product to avoid weighing down your hair.

The John Shelby haircut is a low-maintenance style with an undercut and short crop on top that creates a youthful handsome look. Played by Joe Cole, John Shelby has a thick hairstyle that resembles a longer crew cut or a short comb over with a length that may just be 2 to 3 inches. The sides and back are cut short to highlight the styling above for a fresh and refined look. This cut is popular among modern men as it can be worn naturally and touched up at home with clippers. Just be aware that you will need to trim the hair on top regularly to keep your style looking sharp.
To get John Shelby’s hair, ask your barber for a high bald fade or shaved disconnected on the back and sides. You’ll want to leave some length on top for styling options. Some guys may want to style a hard side part and will need a shaved line for a distinct look. When styling, you can sweep all your hair to the side for a clean comb over, leave it neat for an Ivy League look or create a classic gentlemen’s style with the hard part. For this iconic look, you’ll need a strong pomade or gel with a shiny finish. Use a matte styling product like clay or wax for a natural textured result.

The Michael Gray haircut is a classy style for guys who want a low to medium taper fade on the sides with longer hair on top. Dapper and clean-cut, this classic side part was all the rage in the 1920s and remains a timeless choice that can be easily styled for formal events. While a stylish Peaky Blinder haircut, Michael Gray’s hair offers a fashionable business professional style you can wear to the office as well as your personal life. The suave and sexy aesthetic can also feature a hard part with a shaved line for a bolder look.
To get this haircut, talk to your barber about cutting a side part or comb over with a fade on the sides and back. The longer hair on top can be cut to your desired length. To style this look, you’ll need slightly damp hair and a strong styling product like a pomade or gel with a high shine finish. After sectioning, brush your hair back and to the side in a diagonal direction. Try using a blow dryer with a light heat setting to create subtle waves.

The classic bowl cut is a retro men’s hairstyle that will add some style and originality to your look. With buzzed sides and a straight-line trim across the middle of the forehead that goes all the way around the head, this classic cut can be an attractive and edgy style for some guys. To change things up, you can part your hair down the middle for a vintage 90s look.

The modern bowl cut is a stylish haircut for guys that offers more texture than the classic look, creating a unique fringe style. The modern bowl hairstyle can be paired with a fade or undercut on the sides and back for a strong contrast. Whether you want a tapered cut or a disconnected undercut with buzzed sides, this style has become a recent hair trend that will highlight the longer hair on top. When styling, you’ll want to use a light hold product with a matte finish for a textured and natural look.

The bowl cut fade is a popular hairstyle for men who want to combine classic and modern styles to get a classy look. With so many different types of fades to choose from, you can ask your barber for a low, mid, or high fade haircut. For a youthful touch, some guys will get a taper on the sides and back for a clean-cut and elegant finish. Perfect for short thick hair, the bowl fade offers a versatile and fashionable cut that will make a statement.

The undercut is a stylish haircut that will always look good with a bowl cut. Structured and effortlessly chic, the undercut bowl cut most closely resembles the classic variation, giving you a low-maintenance and cool hairstyle for men who prefer a clean look. If you want short sides cut to one length and the versatility and swagger of longer hair on top, be sure to keep your undercut fresh with frequent visits to the barber. With quality clippers, you can even cut this style at home.

Much like a French crop or other fringe hairstyles, the textured bowl cut has a natural and fuller look for a stylish touch. The textured bowl hairstyle is styled with a matte styling product to achieve a clean-cut and thicker finish, giving the style a more youthful and modern appearance. The buzzed sides offer a clean and flattering contrast to the messy and playful top. Some guys will get the hair in front cut choppy and mixed for an edgy look.

Wavy hair can provide a unique and flattering texture to your bowl cut. This wavy hairstyle will have natural volume and a cool finish, giving it a fuller look. The distinction between the unruly waves and the signature blunt edges also makes for an awesome fashion statement. Although you won’t need any styling products to create texture or volume, we still recommend using alight or medium-hold pomade or wax to keep your hair looking good all day.

The bowl cut with bangs is a popular style that looks charming and fresh. While most cuts keep the hair in front the same length, this bowl haircut emphasizes a longer fringe for a unique look. Great for little boys and teenage guys, the long bangs can be styled down or parted in the middle for a retro style.

The layered bowl cut is a modern style that adds volume and texture to your haircut. A bowl hairstyle with layers can be a great way to create fullness and flow to the cut, taking your look to the next level. Whether you get shaved, undercut or tapered sides, this layered style should be left messy for a modern shag. Use a light to medium hold styling product for a clean and soft finish.

The curly bowl cut is an amazing hairstyle that will let your curls shine for a flattering look. The bowl haircut offers a simple cut for men with curly hair, especially when combined with a taper fade or undercut. Whether you have short or longer hair on top, you’ll want to keep your curls moisturized and healthy for extra volume. When styling trendy curly hairstyles, make sure to apply a light hold pomade or sea salt spray for a balance of control, shine and hydration.

The bowl cut has been a classic haircut for boys that always looks stylish and devilishly handsome. With a taper fade or undercut all around, a boy’s bowl hairstyle is a modern take on the classic look that styles best when textured for a natural look. This low-maintenance short haircut is ideal for little kids and teenage guys since it doesn’t require much styling. Just apply a light hold gel, pomade or spray and brush the hair down for a cool look.

The short bowl cut is a trendy and simple variation of the traditional haircut. Short bowl cuts are perfect for guys who want a low-maintenance and easy look that is still chic and fashionable. Whether you choose a short or very short cut, the style will maintain its modern and youthful vibe. When getting a short bowl haircut, you’ll want to ask your barber for a high bald fade on the sides and back to complement the shorter hair on top. This high and tight hairstyle will look masculine show off your dapper faded sides.

The long bowl cut is a men’s style that was popularized by celebrity icons of the past. With several styling options, the long hair bowl cut looks best when styled messy and shaggy for a carefree finish. Cut around the eyebrows in front and shaped to fall naturally all across the head, this longer style will appeal to men who prefer easy surfer or K-pop hairstyles. In recent years, the longer bowl cut has become a fashionable look for Korean men and is sure to draw attention from the ladies.

Whether you’re a natural blonde or have dyed hair, the bowl cut is meant for you. A blonde bowl cut naturally shows off your fun and sexy hair color, mixing the carefree surfer dude with elements of a fresh, clean style. If you do dye your hair blonde for your bowl haircut, be sure to also invest in a good hair care routine to maintain your platinum locks.

The bowl cut with a low fade is great for guys who want a modern and elegant style. A low fade haircut adds a soft and subtle transition to your bowl fade hairstyle without sacrificing the iconic blunt edges on top. . The gradual tapering can stylishly complement a beard by providing a seamless transition for a sleek touch.

The bowl cut with a mid fade is a cool hairstyle that blends bold and classic styles for a happy medium. The mid fade haircut on the sides and back will raise the hairline all around the head, creating a high-contrast hairstyle that emphasizes the disconnect between the longer hair on top and your sides. This cut is eye-catching and charming, making it sure to draw attention.

The bowl cut with a high fade is a very short men’s haircut that combines these bold styles for a fresh look. Guys can choose from a high skin or taper fade haircut to determine just how short the sides should be cut. Sharp and edgy, the high bowl cut will highlight the thicker long hair on top. Similar to the military-inspired high and tight, growing a beard can add a masculine vibe to any high fade hairstyle and will also serve to offset the generally youthful appearance of the bowl cut.

Straight hair can help you get a bowl cut with the right texture, allowing you to pull off the iconic look with ease. Like the fringe or crop top hairstyle, a straight bowl cut will make styling the signature uniform edges easy. Your hair will fall evenly and lightly in all directions, making the style manageable and low-maintenance. Great for guys with angular features, the natural softness of the style adds balance and dimension to your facial structure. Use a light-hold product like a cream to maximize volume and flow while preventing stray hairs and frizz.

For a bold and daring bowl cut, consider shaving the sides rather than simply buzzing them short. A bowl cut with shaved sides pairs strong, sharp features with an otherwise youthful and fun hairstyle, resulting in a good blend of the masculine and trendy. Feel free to try different variations of shaved sides like a skin fade or shaved undercut to find a look that best suits you.

The Caesar fade is one of the most popular haircuts for men who want to stand out with a short fringe. The Caesar taper fade is cut short on the sides and back to create contrast that will highlight the longer hair on top. There are many different types of fades to consider, including the low, mid and high fade haircuts. You can ask your barber for a skin, bald, drop, burst or taper to further customize your cut. Great with thick, straight, wavy and curly hair, the Caesar fade can be textured and messy for an effortlessly chic style or neat and structured for a classic finish. You’ll want to use a matte hair product like wax, clay or styling cream to get a natural look.

If you prefer to keep your hair neatly trimmed, a short Caesar cut presents you with a fresh take on your standard haircut of choice. Combining a crew cut with a hint of the recognizable Caesar bangs, this is a good alternative if you want to refrain from embracing the full length of the traditional cut.

Men who enjoy the process of styling their hair will love the long Caesar cut. Featuring tapered sides and textured length on top, this haircut is easy to style and even easier to maintain over time. Since the back and sides are typically faded, all you need to worry about is finding the perfect way to sweep your hair over your forehead and you’re good to go.

For a sleeker, more professional option, go for a low Caesar cut. The main elements of this cut are the faded back and sides paired with cropped hair on top. The short length makes it easy to style and you’ll look both masculine and modern.

If you’re in love with the classic elements of the Caesar haircut but you want something more updated, opt for a Caesar with taper and get the best of both worlds. Featuring the same allover length as the traditional cut, this modernized version has faded sides that present you with a cleaner finish.

Look like Liam Hemsworth with your new Caesar style haircut. One of the most popular options, this cut is created by fading the sides and back of your hair while cropping the remaining length on top. When styled using texturized products, the final look is sexy and flattering.

When in Rome, choose a classic Julius Caesar haircut. For this cut, your barber trims your hair to the same length along the back, sides, and front to create a unified style. One of the easiest options to maintain, you’ll be able to wash your hair and head straight out the door. Ultimately, the classic Caesar haircut looks masculine and rugged for a refined Roman hairstyle.

The modern Caesar is a great option for men who want to take their hair to the next level. Talk to your barber about how you want to achieve this cut, as some prefer to give you an undercut or fade along the sides and back and others choose a more traditional option.

Men with textured hair look distinguished with a dark Caesar haircut. To achieve this look, barbers taper, drop, or temper the hair along the sides of your head and along the back. The remaining hair on top is paired down but retains its natural texture, presenting you with a look that’s equal parts sleek and effortless.

A textured Caesar haircut allows you to use the styling products you enjoy without sacrificing the shape of this classic haircut. By using pomade to incorporate added texture to the length on top of your hair, you’ll give yourself a refreshing new look that you’re sure to love.

You may be thinking that you can’t achieve this look with your hair type, but a Caesar cut with curly hair looks just as good as other options. Ask your barber to fade the hair along the back and sides and trim down the length on top since shorter curls are easier to manage.

A Caesar cut for black men is one of the most stylish haircuts of the modern era. Your barber gives you a tapered fade along the sides and back of your hair while allowing your natural waves to shine through on top. Ask for any fade you prefer, as many options are available and pair well with the traditional Caesar elements.

The light Caesar haircut is perfect because it’s suitable for men with every type and style of hair. Whether your hair is thick or thin, this haircut presents you with a clean-cut look and a touch of added volume.

Look effortlessly handsome with a messy Caesar haircut. Ask your barber for added layers when you’re getting your hair cut to achieve this look and add a few products to gain the style you desire most. Perfect for men who like to experiment with their hair to determine which cut suits them best.

If your hairline is receding or you’re beginning to bald at the front of your head, a Caesar haircut for balding men is a flattering option. By combing the hair forward and neatening up the sides and back, you look more polished and you’ll feel more confident as well.

To help you visualize the disconnected undercut and determine whether it’s a good look for you, check out the variety of classic disconnected haircuts below. From an undercut with short hair to variations for long hair, you’ll find the best disconnected undercut hairstyles to try right now.

Nom: Textured Slicked Back Hair with Disconnected Undercut
Disconnected Undercut with Textured Spiky Hair
Textured Pomp Comb Over with Hard Part
High Skin Fade with Combed Over Pompadour
Disconnected Short Pompadour with Hard Part
Undercut with Beard and Side Swept Top
Disconnected Brushed Back Hair with Beard
Messy Brushed Up Hair with Short Sides
Slicked Back Hair with Disconnected Sides
Long Comb Over + Undercut + Full Beard
Description: The comb over undercut has been a popular way to style this short haircut. Adding a rugged beard to the mix just completes the look.

Nom: Side Part + Undercut + Full Messy Beard
Description: A messy, full beard epitomizes manliness, yet the addition of the side part is a nice way to keep the look classy.
The slicked back undercut has been a favorite men’s hairstyle for years now.

Nom: Textured Brush Back + Undercut + Long Beard
Description: As textured styles continue to trend this year, we’ve been seeing more brush back hairstyles. Because of its length and versatility, we highly recommend this cut!
Dyed or bleach hair is another sexy look that’s becoming more common nowadays, so try platinum or bleach blonde for a change.

Nom: Wavy Textured Top + Shaved Undercut + Thick Beard
Description: Shaved sides work well with most hairstyles, and wavy hair just adds volume to this style.
The classic long beard and undercut combination looks like a natural fit.
This longer undercut doesn’t follow the traditional cut, but can be a great business style.

Nom: Comb Over Undercut + Thick Bushy Beard
Description: The comb over haircut is an excellent option for guys with straight, textured hair.
This messy pomp allows for many different styling choices.

Nom: Shaved Sides + Full Beard + Comb Over
Description: Pairing a full beard with shaved sides and a trendy modern comb over makes for an irresistible look women won’t forget!

Nom: Undercut Fade + Brush Back + Long Beard
Description: The undercut fade offers a beautiful balance between the undercut and different types of fades.

Nom: Messy Medium Length + Undercut + Long Full Beard
Description: This messy medium length hairstyle is styled to perfection. The thick, full beard will take some time to grow, but the final look is well-worth the wait.

Nom: Undercut + Long Side Swept Hair + Beard
Description: Men with long hair and beards are blessed with the opportunity to style so many cool hairstyles!

Nom: Slick Back Top + Undercut Sides + Long Beard
Description: If you thought the slick back on top and undercut on the sides couldn’t be a work-appropriate style, think again!
Here are what some of the best top knots look like in action. From the undercut top knot to man braids, check out these cool long hair styles to see if this look might work for you!

Nom: Thick Comb Over + Classic Taper + Full Beard
Messy Quiff + Short Sides + Full Beard
Low Skin Fade + Hard Part Side Part
Medium Length Slick Back + Long Beard
Long Comb Over Undercut + Full Beard
High Fade + Hard Part Comb Over
Tapered Sides + Textured Brushed Up + Long Beard
Side Swept Fringe + Fade + Short Beard

Description: Without a doubt, the classic flow back is a cool and confident style for the man who wants a smooth layered look. The cut is simple and can be achieved by brushing the hair back and letting it fall naturally. For a simple finish, let your hair dry or run a small amount of pomade through to embrace your inner heartthrob.

The bro flow is a popular long layered haircut for men who want to feature volume, movement and fullness. Undeniably iconic, the flow is an easy and simple style for the man who keeps his hair on the longer end. Adding texture throughout will allow the layers to give the overall look shape while remaining rugged. Whether you’re trying to be the bad boy or the boy next door, the versatility of this cut will only enhance your masculinity.

A brush back with a fade is a versatile and cool layered hairstyle for men who want volume and styling flexibility for an irresistible look. In some ways, this style is a throwback to every main character in the TV shows you watched growing up. This textured and layered hairstyle can be the ideal look for guys who want to embrace their youth and attraction. Keep the length longer in the front and shorter towards the back to show off the windswept illusion and throw in a fade to accentuate the volume.

The high-volume layered look is worn by the most laidback of gentlemen. Think of the surfer with a chill demeanor who spends all day in the ocean catching waves. The look can be achieved simply by adding a bit of sea salt spray to damp hair for some added grit and texture. Mess around with the blow dryer to give it the extra boost it needs to lock in the volume, and you’ll be good to go.

The layered and choppy look is a fun option for the guy who likes to keep their aesthetic laidback, subtle, and trendy. This deliberately unstructured cut is achieved by keeping the back and sides short and crisp, which allows the texture on top to stand out. Stick to a high-hold clay to solidify the look and keep the choppiness at a maximum.

Long layered hairstyles are effortlessly chic and elegant looks for men who want to showcase their texture, fullness and body. Longer layers will only enhance your style by adding much more flow while removing weight that would otherwise make the look heavy. If you’ve been blessed with beautiful hair, layering your longer style with take your look to the next level.

If you like the look of being caught in gale-force winds, then the blowout fade may be the style you’re looking for. Defined by its height and structure, this cut features eye-catching volume that almost defies gravity. While the back and sides are kept closer to the skin, you can keep your hair in place by using pomade or gel to help direct it.

For the gentleman who wants to keep their hair long and in control, the brushed back comb over style is a fashionably current option. Adding layers on top will let the texture stand out without sacrificing any length and disconnecting the sides will let the top cascade over the faded sides. This is a sleek cut for any occasion.

This cut is perfect if you’re looking for something edgy, yet approachable. Similar to the brush back, the brush up keeps the hair longer up front to give the overall look some height, but instead of combed back it’s pushed up with clay or any other strong hold product. A mid-skin fade adds some necessary contrast to the cut allowing every element to pop.

If you want to show off how edgy you can be, look no further than the hard side part. Like the traditional cut it’s named after, this variation shaves a line where the hair naturally parts to create precise lines for a sharper appearance. Rock a fade for some added contrast and lock in the look with some gel. You won’t have a hair out of place.

This cut is famously worn by George Clooney and for good reason. It’s short, easy to maintain, full of character, and a cinch to achieve. Defined by a horizontal fringe, this look is great for highlighting your features and adding depth. Rocking this cut with pomade will only enhance the overall style while making sure you’re the center of attention.

The crew cut is a classic short hairstyle for men who want a masculine and simple option. A layered crew cut can give your hair more direction, while still being manly and sharp. You can put the product away for this one and let it sit naturally for a textured finish.

A layered curly hair fade is a trendy style that will stand out and make a statement. Some might see the kinkiness of curly hair difficult to manage, but in reality, its versatility makes it a hot commodity. Textured and short curly styles with layers often look bouncier and less dense. You can even make it low-maintenance by asking for a fade to keep the look tight.

The faux hawk fade is a layered style that has stood the test of time and is still as punk as ever without the commitment. As a less extreme mohawk, layering the top will make it look less dense while also adding the illusion of fullness. Add in some gel or clay and you’ll be the most daring gent in the club.

A part with bangs can be a cool choice for any guy that wants to get ahead of the trends. Taking all the most fashionable aspects of the side part and the fringe, this style is a handsome, casual and timeless look. While the cut works best on the longer side, the layers won’t make the hair feel like it’s a block on your head. You can even use some mousse to give it hold throughout the day.

For a modern take on a classic look, the pompadour fade is a cool style to talk about with your barber. To attain the pompadour, you’ll need to get a decent amount of length at the front of the head and then use a blow dryer and a small round brush to train the hair up and over the top, creating a bump. This can be made easier with layers, as the strands won’t be as stubborn to work with. Break out the pomade to seal the deal because this is what it was made for!

The layered quiff is an exceptional cut that lets men with thicker hair embrace their natural volume, even at a longer length. Layers help loosen the look, allowing for greater versatility in styling. Whether you need it neat for a work event or casual for a night out, this cut is above all the rest.

The side swept style is a low-maintenance and smooth cut that features a clipped back and sides while the top is left much longer for a dapper finish. Layers help with the flow and allow the hair to lay gentler over the sides. This look is perfect for the guy who’s ready for anything.

Stylish as ever, a fringe is a timeless cut for the man who wants to show off their rugged jawline. Kept hanging over your forehead or cropped shorter for ease, this cut can be as versatile as you need it to be. If you need a sexy, go-to cut for the long term, look no further.

If you need a neat cut that needs very little effort, then the ivy league is one you’ll want to ask for. Similar to the Caesar, this style is iconic and is characterized by the top being left much longer than the back and sides. Layering will show pizzazz and breathe new life into the look.

The middle part is having a moment in pop culture and the time to try one is now. Ideal for the guy who doesn’t like to keep their hair too long or too short, this style has a parting down the middle, which keeps the hair out of your face. Layers will help soften the part and give some life to what could easily be considered a more tired look.

If one thing was to remain from 2020, let it be the rebirth of the modern mullet. It’s rebellious and fun and not every guy can pull it off. As is tradition, the hair is kept long in the back, while the sides are taken in short, and layering the longer parts of the cut keeps it light and sleek.

The mohawk will forever be a bold look. Adding layers only helps that by giving texture and flow to a cut that would otherwise be held straight up with gel. This version adds a low skin fade to give the style more depth and intrigue without looking as extreme as its namesake. Spend some time with a blow dryer and pomade, and you’ll be ready to rock and roll.

Whether you want to wear it medium or long, loose or shaggy, the mop top is the epitome of easygoing. While this cut may lean on the younger side, men of any age can try it out to see what all the fuss is about. The mop is made better with layers because the added texture helps give it a unique movement that it wouldn’t otherwise have.

If you want to look red carpet ready, then the slick back undercut is what you want to ask for. The undercut keeps the back and sides uniform and close to the scalp while layering the top allows for a seamless flow and crazy definition. Slick the top back and over with some pomade and it doesn’t get any easier than that.

Popularized in South Korea by countless boy bands, the two block is a modern hairstyle for men that has made its way overseas and is here to stay. The eastern cousin of the middle part, this style showcases a sharp part down the center of the head, and texture is added to give its characteristic bounce and volume. A light styling product can lock in the look without overpowering it.

While wavy hair can be elusive and enviable, the guys who are born with it are blessed with beachy hair that doesn’t require a ton of effort. Adding layers to this style helps add even more wave and body to the look. Depending on the event, you can choose to part it with a comb and some product or let it hang loose and natural.

The long and flowing two block haircut can be a cool look for a guy who wants to keep the top longer for that young heartthrob vibe. The cut still showcases a part down the middle, but adding layers lets the hair on the top of the head flow more carefree over the sides.

Sweeping longer hair to the side is a great way to show off a man’s face while still adding a bit of personality. Longer layered hair can take a guy from basic to trendy without all the time and effort. Using a sea salt spray will help add some grit to the style without feeling dirty or heavy.

Long layered straight hair is an effortlessly cool look for guys who want to feature volume and movement to flowing locks. This sexy and longer straight hairstyle looks great with texture and can be used to bring out your inner playboy.

A twist on the modern comb over, more and more guys are asking for layers on top to help with texture and body. For a classic vibe, ask your barber for tapered sides to give the look structure and body. Grab a scoop of pomade or a dime-sized amount of gel to let your ruggedness pop.

Nom: Messy Fringe with Short Layered Top
Description: The fringe is a tried-and-true cut for the guy who is always after the latest clean-cut look. Keeping the top short and layered lets the messiness take center stage while a taper helps round out the look. For an even more irresistible approach, jostle the bangs when styling so they land randomly over your forehead.

A messy layered hairstyle is a suitable look for the busy professional man who needs to get up and go every morning without missing a beat. This cut can be done up with or without product, as the intensity of the layers is only improved the messier it gets. Skip the shampoo for a few days for an even grungier look.

Like the traditional approach, the modern Caesar cut is still a short and easy-to-maintain style for every guy. Adding texture with a razor on top, gives less rigidity to the fringe. You can create a messy look by scrunching up sections of your hair with styling clay to emphasize its character.

A textured quiff is a good cut for the younger gentleman. The height of the style is enhanced by layers and gives off the vibe that you’re someone who likes to go out and have a good time. A medium-hold product like a styling cream can help produce a lasting, natural hold.

For the guy who wants to commit and take their faux hawk fade to the next level, we’d recommend the mohawk fade. Leaning hard into its punk roots, the sides are disconnected from the top to create the hawk. Whereas the traditional look would go super short on the sides, this approach features a fade to add cleanliness and depth. Have fun and add some lines into the fade to show everyone that you’re different.

The asymmetrical fringe can be a helpful departure if you’re tired of the rigidity of a blunt bang. This option creates a softer appearance with the way it falls over the forehead and ensures that no hair is ever in the same place twice. With layers, the look will have varying lengths and volume, perfect for the non-traditional guy.

The surfer haircut is simple and unstructured and meant for the laidback guy who wants to catch the waves every morning. Have your barber mess around with layering to add choppiness and form. Then let your hair air dry after the shower to emphasize your wavy locks.

Nom: Textured Blowout with Faded Sides and Line Up
Description: Ideal for the guy who likes a look that stands out for the right reasons, the blowout is recognizable thanks to its insane volume and a fade that will keep the back and sides short. Adding in a line up keeps everything crisp and clean, while adding texture offers movement on top.

The humble brush back style is an elegant look on guys who like texture and flow for an iconic finish. While fades are gaining in popularity, you can never go wrong with a classic taper. Keeping more weight on the back and sides and layering the top allows for a fuller look for the distinguished gentleman.

The textured French crop is a trendy and charming style for guys who want to create effortless texture and flow with their hair. Adding a variety of layers in different sections of the head updates this traditional cut. Use a low-shine pomade for dimension, throw in a medium fade for some contrast, and you’ll be ready for anything.

For a throwback with sex appeal, spiky hair is a bold look for guys that has been upgraded with texture for a fuller finish. The layered spikes add new dimensions to the style, while a high taper keeps it neat without going super short. A clay product is your best friend here to make this style a home run.

Thick and textured short hairstyles with layers are a trendy choice that can make styling faster and easier without a sacrifice. Have your barber or stylist throw in some light texture to the top to loosen the density and ask for a high fade to strike some contrast. No product is necessary here.

A thick and layered brush back offers a classic approach for the modern gentleman who wants to show the world how much volume he can pull off. Adding layers throughout will let the texture stand out without feeling too heavy. For a finishing touch, befriend your blow dryer and a small round brush to put each strand in its place.

For a bold and popular hairstyle, try asking for an undercut. It’s perfect for the man who loves versatility as the back and sides are kept clipped short and uniform, while the top is left longer to showcase waves and texture. Layers, in this case, help with movement and volume.

Nom: Blonde Textured Spikes with Low Bald Fade
Description: Blonde textured spikes with a low bald fade is a stylish choice for guys who want a bold look that offers visual appeal. This modern hairstyle starts with a tapered cut on the sides and back to contrast the longer hair on top. You can use a strong matte styling product to shape the short spiky hair for a clean finish.

Nom: Messy Textured Pompadour with High Skin Fade
Description: A messy and textured pompadour with a high skin fade is a bold and stylish look that creates volume and movement for a fashionable finish. This trendy take on the classic style offers a cool bad-boy look that will stand out and get noticed by everyone. The skin fade provides a low-maintenance cut on the sides while the volume and length create ample styling opportunities.

A blowout with a low skin fade is a high-volume style that offers dimension and edge for a cool vibe. The low taper fade is a classy option for men who need a versatile and professional haircut, while the thick straight locks make styling effortless. Use a texturizing pomade or clay and a quality blow dryer to create a flawless style.

Nom: Cool Curly Hair with Short Fade
Description: Cool curly hair with a short fade is a fresh and easy style for guys who were born with a tighter hair texture. The curls can add eye-popping definition and the short fade would keep the overall look clean and professional. Left to air-dry after a shower or styled with some mousse, this cut is perfect for the guy struggling with their curly locks.

A textured quiff is a classic and timeless style that lets the gents with thicker hair embrace their natural volume, even at a longer length. Whether you keep it neat for a dapper look with some medium-shine pomade or mess it up with some matte clay for the fresh-out-of-bed look, you can rest assured that you’re still the most stylist guy around.

You can ask your barber for a burst fade with a mohawk to create an edgy and rebellious look that’s wearable everywhere. Style this modern mohawk with a strong product to create a style that will always stand out. While from the front, the fade is kept nice and tight, the back tapers into a mohawk, adding a bit of edge.

The comb over with undercut style is for the guy who wants to add some height to their look without a ton of effort. Ask your stylist to add some texture to the top, so the cut can maintain its easygoing nature without falling under the weight of the product. Comb some medium shine pomade through and you’re ready to hit the ground running!

Nom: Full Brushed Back Hair with Long Sides
Description: Thick brushed back hair can be a classy and cool style that works well for professional men who also want to look good outside of the office. With a full beard, this masculine hairstyle will attractive women all around. Use a medium-hold styling product to develop a textured finish while maintaining shape and control.

Nom: Messy Brushed Up Hair with Short Sides
Description: Messy brushed up hair with short sides is a trendy look for modern guys who want to emphasize all the texture on top. Ideal for summer, you really can’t go wrong getting it done in the dead of winter. A strong matte clay or pomade will ensure that the spikes pop.

If you’re looking to keep your hair long but you still like to add a bit of pop to your style, then grab some pomade and slick it all back for this timeless look. The undercut keeps the back and sides short and uniform and lets the top flow seamlessly on top of it for wild definition.

A long fringe with tapered sides is the ideal look for guys who want to keep a strong contrast between the top and sides. The taper fade will keep the look fresh and professional. Run over the top with a matte product to accentuate and lock in texture.

The faux hawk fade is a trendy option for the dapper gent who prefers a bold and daring hairstyle that will have all the eyes on him. This cut can be paired with a skin taper for a manly edge while adding a shaved line or two can help highlight your masculine features.

Nom: Long Brush Back Hair with Low Taper Fade
Description: The long brush back look is a timeless cut that will look simple and dapper with a low taper fade on the sides to complement the style. To get ready, comb through and add some light-hold product.

The mohawk with a drop combines tapered sides that go lower as the fade reaches the back of the head. The top can be cropped short or kept to create a daring style that’s surprisingly easy to work with. The beauty of the drop fade is that it softens the typical punk rocker look and trades it in for one that leans more professional.

Nom: Short Hair with Brushed Up Fringe and Low Bald Fade
Description: If you need a cut that’s easy to work with, a short haircut with a brushed up fringe and low fade can be a stylish choice. The cropped top and longer bangs add height to your look without getting out of control, and with a low bald fade, guys can use a matte product for a textured, effortless look.

For the guy who likes a traditional look with a ton of volume, the parted quiff is one to move to the top of the list. Both charming and confident, this cut is perfect for the young professional who likes to stand out amongst his colleagues. Adding some texturizing spray and a bit of pomade before parting the hair will help add great detail to the completed appearance.

Nom: High Volume Comb Over with High Fade
Description: The high volume comb over is an effortlessly cool haircut for all seasons that allows guys to style any look for any event. Ask your barber for a high fade to keep the top looking more voluminous. The result should be a heavily textured style that can be easily brushed back and tousled with pomade or clay.

There is nothing easier than having messy long hair. Like the man bun, all it takes is skipping on your barber entirely and letting it grow. You can use some dry shampoo in the morning to help give it that beachy look without having to skip a few showers or you can just tie it up to get it out of the way!

Nom: Short Messy Hair with Low Skin Fade
Description: Ideal for men seeking a cut that’s easy to maintain, the short messy look is one to keep your eyes on. The top is left shorter in the back and longer in the front to give you some length to play with and the low skin fade adds a subtle edge. With some styling clay, this style is versatile and can be done messy for a casual look or coiffed for nights out.

Nom: Side Swept Fringe with Mid Fade
Description: The side swept fringe is a low-maintenance cut that features a clipped back and sides while the top is left much longer for a sharp, devil-may-care look. You can push the hair to the side with a strong-hold pomade or let it hang loose, providing versatility and a youthful approach. This cut is perfect for summers spent at the beaches.

Nom: Spiked Bangs with Shaved Sides and Line Design
Description: The spiked bangs are a classic style that dates back to 80s grunge. Kept high and stiff with gel or pomade, this look can be enhanced with tightly shaved sides and a pop of color. You can ask your barber to shave in some line designs to the side to add an uncommon edginess that will have every guy stealing your look.

Nom: Textured French Crop with Skin Fade
Description: The textured French crop is a trendy and charming style for guys who want to create effortless texture and flow with their hair. The traditional cut is enhanced with low-shine pomade for dimension, a skin fade for some contrast, and bangs that are pushed forward to highlight crisp features.

Nom: Textured Spiky Hair with Mid Skin Fade and Shaved Part
Description: This trendy and textured style can be a great way to set yourself apart from every other guy. The sides are kept tight with the skin fade and the top is left outrageously longer to get those distinct spikes. Incorporate shaved lines and highlights for a result that turns heads.

Whether you want the sexy boy-band look or a trending K-Pop style, the two block is a popular choice for modern men. Essentially a middle part cut, the two block divides the top of your head into symmetrical sections and is textured to lay messily over clipped sides. Add in some lightweight product to add some movement or keep it clean, the result will always be on point.

For the guy that wants a low-maintenance and traditional look, the buzz cut fade is ideal. Using only clippers, the top is kept short and neat while the sides are taken into the skin. The buzz cut can be a great way to maintain a masculine look that doesn’t require any effort.

The curly fringe is a youthful style for guys blessed with beachy waves and tons of volume. Adding in a high fade makes for a cut with a ton of contrast that will make you stand out in a crowd for all the right reasons. A touch of sea salt spray and texturizing pomade will give this style a bouncy and slightly tousled appearance.

The modern pompadour is the epitome of classy. It screams impressive with its length and lift and the faded sides help keep the look symmetrical. Achieving an all-day hold is simple with a small amount of medium-weight pomade, a comb and a light spritz of hairspray. You can even pair this cut with a perfectly lined up beard to add balance to your face and an overall sharpness to your look.

Nom: Hard Side Part with Low Taper
Description: A hard side part with a low taper allows guys to create a clean and textured cut that ensures you remain dapper. The deep shaved part and low taper help add a strong contrast with the neatness of the sides and the height on top. When styling, use pomade and a blow dryer to infuse volume that won’t quit.

Nom: High and Tight with Razor Faded Sides
Description: A high and tight fade with razor faded sides is a popular cut for guys that like to keep their style low maintenance with the top kept short and the sides even shorter. The razor fade keeps the contrast dramatic without sacrificing ease.

Nom: Brush Cut with Low Skin Fade and Beard
Description: A brush cut with a low skin fade is perfect for guys who want something low-maintenance, sharp, and masculine. Keeping the skin fade low makes for a tidy cut while the well-groomed beard adds symmetry to the overall look. Use a bit of matte styling product over the top for the rugged and textured finish.

Nom: Long Comb Over with Tapered Sides
Description: If you rock a no-nonsense punk look, the long comb over is a cut that will add that extra bit of edginess. Keeping the top long will add a ton of weight and movement, while the tapered sides keep it looking clean. Add a touch of sea salt spray for a bit of grittiness without the residue of a heavier product.

Nom: Short Brushed Forward Top with Disconnected Undercut
Description: Like the traditional fringe, a short brushed forward look is an achievable cut for someone who doesn’t want to put in a ton of effort when getting ready for their day. Pairing it with a disconnected undercut will help keep the overall style looking sharp while breaking away from the traditional fade.

Nom: Brushed Up Style with Mid Taper
Description: A brush up with a mid taper is a stylish modern style for guys who want a short, textured and low-maintenance look. While it starts with a tapered cut on the sides and back to keep everything tight, the hair is left longer on top to add height and definition. Using a light hold product and hairspray will keep this easy-going look intact from day to night.

A man bun is a simple and versatile year-round look that never goes out of style. While growing it out may take time, you can rest assured that all it takes is to stop going to the barber! Guys can pull back long locks into a man bun or let their hair flow for a casual look. Whether you grow a long beard or keep it trimmed, you’ll stand out for all the right reasons.

Nom: Messy Short Curly Hair with Undercut Fade
Description: Short curly hair can be more difficult to manage than straight styles, but embracing natural curls during the summer offers a fresh and flexible look. Add in some gel or cream to define your coils, and then pair it with cropped sides for some flair.

Nom: Modern Bowl Cut with Low Taper Fade
Description: A modern bowl cut with a low taper fade offers a fresh take that adds texture on top while keeping the fringe in front straight and orderly. Have your barber give you a low taper fade to keep things tidy and run some pomade through to let your fringe pop.

Nom: Short Wavy with Low Taper Fade
Description: For the gentleman blessed with wavy looks but without a clue what to do with them, try asking your barber to keep the top short and tidy. Suited for the summer, this look can be achieved with or without product, and the low taper fade keeps it from looking overgrown too soon after the cut.

A side part with faded sides offers the chance to create a voluminous and textured cut that instantly screams classic gentleman. The clean part and faded sides provide contrast with the volume on top. To finish the look, brush it back with matte pomade for instant lift.

Nom: Short Crew Cut with High Fade
Description: A short crew is a popular haircut for those who want to avoid buzzing it all off. The high fade adds a modern edge to the classic look and will keep you cool all summer long. Whether you’re clean-shaven or rocking a well-trimmed beard, this cut will always be masculine.

Nom: Side Swept Ivy League with Mid Taper
Description: A side swept Ivy League is an easy cut that features a cropped top and tapered back and sides. Pushing it to the side with a strong pomade adds unrivaled texture and shine to your overall appearance. This cut is ideal for the guy who keeps his style fresh, sharp, and approachable.

Nom: Swept Crew Cut with High Fade
Description: While it ventures close to military-inspired style, the side swept crew cut sets itself apart with its versatility. Left slightly longer in the front and going shorter in the back, the swept crew cut is a low-maintenance and fashionable approach. All you have to do is add a bit of gel to the front to get the hair off your face and lock in your style.

A wavy bro flow is a practical cut that works well for men who don’t want to spend time styling their mane before heading out to catch some waves. You can leave your locks natural or spritz sea salt spray for a beachy look with a ton of volume. For a nighttime look, gently push the hair backward with pomade for a suave and effortlessly sexy look.

Nom: Thick French Crop with High Fade
Description: The thick French crop is a haircut that’s versatile enough to accommodate any simple styling ideas. You can push it forward with a bit of clay or push it up with some pomade, every result will be outstanding. Pair it with a high fade for something sleek and fashionable.

The greaser hairstyle is a retro look that was popular throughout the 50s and 60s. A greaser style generally uses a slick styling product to create a bad-boy look for young men. The style features short to medium-length hair on top that has been slicked back with some styling product like a pomade, wax, or gel. These days, it is common to pair this look with an undercut or a deep side part, but the traditional style was paired with a mid fade.

The classic pompadour is a cool and handsome haircut for men who want a style that will stand out. The hair on top is left three or more inches long and swept upward away from the face, then held in place with strong hairspray, pomade, or gel. The sides can be cut into a short taper, a fade, or an undercut. The classic variation of this cut is neat and slick, but the more modern takes can incorporate texture or emphasize natural waves.

The messy quiff is a popular hairstyle for men who want a modern twist on a classic style. As a style that became mainstream after Elvis and James Dean, the quiff is characterized by its sheer volume, which is usually three or more inches high just above the forehead. The messy look applies to the voluminous section of hair, which often boasts a bit of disheveled fringe. The contemporary version of the cut emphasizes the difference in length top and the sides, but the traditional version is much softer and far less severe.

The slick side part is a dapper look that was commonly worn in formal settings. This classy hairstyle features a pronounced part with shiny, slick hair that runs almost perfectly perpendicular to the side. While most modern gentlemen prefer a textured look, the 1950s side part can be achieved with an oil-based pomade and a standard comb for that perfect wet finish. While you can choose a taper on the sides and back, a skin fade offers the contrast for a bold touch.

The wavy swoop pompadour fade is a modern adaptation of the classic pomp that combines several elements of other 50s styles. It starts with the traditional 50s-style pomp and a sleek taper fade on the sides, but rather than styling the hair straight upward or slightly off to one side, this style has a very defined swoop. Start with slightly damp hair, apply a strong gel that maintains its wet look, and then direct the hair just behind the forehead upward. Then, carefully tuck the ends of this section of hair just behind the volume to create the wave that gives this look its character.

The textured cowlick is a hairstyle that plays on the funny bit of swirled hair that can appear on the back of the head. While the natural cowlick is almost always found at the crown of the head, with this style, it can be placed anywhere – including the front of the hair. A cowlick can be paired with a quiff, a modified ducktail, or even a high pompadour.

The textured pompadour is a variation of the popular pomp that relies on the thickness of the hair, the addition of layers, and perhaps some heat styling to achieve its volume. Made popular by Johnny Cash, this rugged take on the pomp calls for slightly longer tapered hair around the back and sides with a very noticeable “bump” at the front. This cut is best for men who have thicker, coarser hair and a few natural waves.

The short sides with textured top hairstyle is a classic look that was made popular by Frank Sinatra, who wore it for much of his professional career. This is a hairstyle created more by styling than the cut, and it starts with a slightly longer version of a gentleman’s cut. All your hair must be brushed back with the crown brushed slightly upward and back to shape the look.

The classic ducktail is a unique variation of more common slicked-back styles. From the front, the ducktail looks just like any other greaser cut. At the back of the head, the precision of the cut and styling creates the illusion of a part that looks almost exactly like the rear-end of a duck. To recreate the look, you’ll need a talented barber or stylist who can cut the sides of your hair very precisely, and you’ll also need to keep up with your regular trims.

The short pompadour is exactly what its name suggests – a traditional pompadour with only a small amount of height. Back in the 1950s, the classic pomp was popular, but it was often viewed as cheeky or edgy for its time. The shorter variation of the cut made it more accessible to men and younger boys. Famous actors like Sean Connery favored the short pompadour since it provided an interesting and versatile but subtler look.

When heartthrob James Dean was spotted sporting a messy quiff, it quickly became one of the most coveted styles of the decade. The cut features longer hair on the top and front paired with shorter hair on the back and sides. It’s comparable to a pompadour, but rather than pushing all the hair on top upward and back, only the front section of hair stands tall with a quiff. The style can be messy, sleek, or something in between.

The gentleman’s side part is the ultimate traditional haircut that exudes class, sophistication and respect. The hair on top is just slightly longer than the hair on the sides and back, and the top section of hair is brushed or combed over from a side part. There are countless ways to wear the style, whether you prefer it to look wet and textured or more natural. This is one of the easiest cuts for barbers and stylists, and as long as you keep up with trims, it’s also one of the easiest styles to recreate at home.

The slick back is a retro style that encompasses a stylish almost-gangster look. In a broad sense, the style involves using a styling product to “slick” the hair back and away from the face. One of the most popular options is the slick side part made famous by actor Cary Grant. This look starts with a traditional gentleman’s cut with some extra length and a very pronounced side part. The hair on the sides, back and top is slicked back to create a cool finish.

The crew cut is a short hairstyle for guys who want a low-maintenance and masculine look. In the 50s, the cut was viewed as wholesome and clean, and because it was easy to style and maintain, it quickly became a favorite among the military. It’s a simple style that consists of hair trimmed very close to the head, and it is slightly longer on the top than it is on the sides and in the back. The traditional form of the cut involved shaving the sides and back or incorporating a skin fade.

The flat top is a stylish and edgy choice for guys that offered a rebellious look. Military men, young college guys and little boys flocked to their barbers for this somewhat spiky yet still gentlemanly cut. While the sides and back of the hair resemble the classic gentleman’s cut, all the action happens at the top. The barber or stylist brushes the hair at the top of the head straight up and uses scissors or trimmers to clip in the illusion of a flat surface. The flat top can be very short like a crew cut, but modern versions have seen the hair reach several inches long.

Also known as the brush cut, the butch cut is a very short military-inspired style. Similar to a crew cut, the main difference between a butch and crew haircut is the butch comes with short hair all over while the crew often features tapered sides. The hair is the same length on the sides and in the back, and only slightly longer on top. Back then, this look was popular in the military and among athletes. The same holds true for modern times.

Conked hair was a popular look for black men from the 1920s through the 1950s and beyond. To achieve the style, stylists used lye to relax and straighten the hair, then created this signature 50s hairstyle. The conk was mostly viewed as a formal style since the lye would burn and damage the hair when used repeatedly. Modern relaxers are still potent, but they are far gentler.

The short afro is a versatile and stylish haircut style for black men who want to maintain healthy natural hair with ease. The style gained popularity because it looked handsome and clean without the need for harmful chemicals. This cut is the predecessor to the huge afros that made their way onto the scene in the 1960s and 1970s.

The jelly roll is named after the shape that the finished style resembles, creating a dramatic and daring style from the 1950s. The hair on top was grown quite long, then combed upward and in to create a loop or rolling wave that looked just like a jelly roll. In some styles, just one roll was placed on the side of the head opposite the part. In others, two rolls were placed directly on top of the head. The modern version is subtler, but it is still viewed as daring and different.

The modern brush back can be defined as a mix between a traditional pompadour and a slick back style. The cut requires longer hair on the top and along the crown and a mid fade on the sides. The longer sections of hair are brushed back and slightly upward, and while some texture may be incorporated into the style, it generally does not boast the wet look that was so common in the 50s.

If you imagine a voluminous pompadour combined with a mohawk, you can almost picture the stylish pomp fringe with fade style. Like the classic pomp, the hair on top is left long and piled high behind the forehead, but it is also lifted and pulled forward to create a mohawk-like fringe. The sides are kept short with a taper fade, and the addition of a line up to clean up the neck and sideburns gives this look even more bad boy personality.

Like most modern variations, the rockabilly jelly roll is a retro hairstyle that has stood the test of time but boasts a toned-down and subtler look. The shape of the roll is visible, and the short sides of the hair create contrast, but the simple addition of thick curls and fringe helps to balance the look in a more contemporary way.

The thick flow-back with ducktail style combines the unique appearance of the ducktail with the flow or flow-back style that became popular during the Victorian era. It involves growing the hair to between two and three inches long, then styling it so that the hair moves straight back and perpendicular to the face. The goal is to cut and style the hair so that when it is brushed back, it creates the illusion of a duck tail at the very center of the back of the head.

A cool breaker was a cut that played on the unique waves that women often wore in their hair as far back as the 1920s. It consists of longer hair on top and short hair on the back and sides, about the same as required for a pompadour. Styling involved using combs, heat tools, and various products to create a pompadour-like shape that consists of long, thick waves moving backward from the forehead.

Nom: Coiffed Waves with High Skin Fade
Description: Coiffed waves with a high skin fade are a stylish look for guys who want a bad-boy appearance with a retro feel. The cut is shaped like a French crop with long hair on top and a high or mid skin fade on the sides, but rather than brushing very short hair forward toward the forehead, heat tools are used to create carefully-shaped waves that move across the head from left to right.

Modern side-swept hair looks have been adapted from the classic cuts of the 1950s. Some cuts are slightly long and involve sweeping the hair back and to the side, but others are kept short enough to incorporate some trendy spikes or a disheveled appearance. Many of the most popular cuts incorporate pompadour-like height, skin fade undercuts, and other features designed to create significant contrast.

The cropped top with an undercut is a short haircut that looks like a crew cut but with longer hair. The longer section of hair starts at each corner of the forehead, and the sides are all one length without any kind of taper or fade. This versatile cut can be spiked up, tousled, slicked back or brushed forward.

Lionel Messi is one of the most famous soccer players in the world who takes to the pitch with a scissor-cut style and faded sides. When looking for cool haircuts, Messi has had many stylish and athletic styles on and off the field in recent years.
